Posts.Content: Hi walkkt Welcome to the online community. You are in the right place - we are a very friendly supportive group of people at various stages of treatment, all only too willing to help. My, it does sound as though you have a lot on and it is lovely of you to be trying to support your friend while also supporting your husband. Please do make sure that you look after yourself as well. You are welcome to come here or call the helpline (0808 808 00 00 Mon-Fri 9am-8pm) if you ever feel that you need some support or even just a rant or someone to talk to.  As for how to support your friend - well, we are all different so what she wants will be individual to her - you might find that just having someone who will listen will be enough for her.  Sometimes people don't like to talk about cancer so it can be hard to try to keep the grim reality of it to yourself. I had lots of supportive text messages from friends and colleagues which was lovely, but there was one friend who I knew I could call on for the less cheery stuff - she came and bought headgear with me when my hair fell out, came to see me when I couldn't go out etc. It was just nice to have someone there who behaved as though it was a perfectly normal thing and would be very open about everything. Cancer was pretty much my whole life for nearly a year and she just got on board with it. Chemo can be tough - we have a chemo club thread in this group and the first page has some tips and advice - you could have a read of that or even point her towards it if you feel she might like to come and join us here. I see you've been posting about your husband, so just wanted to let you know we have a very friendly and supportive Family and Friends group if you ever want to chat to others in your position Sending some virtual hugs your way as you may need them - being strong for others is hard work. R

Posts.Content: Hi Dujo Welcome to the online community - sorry to hear about your side effects. This is quite a common topic here. The post you are replying to is quite old - nothing wrong with that but those posting might not still be using the site. This reply will bump it up the list a bit and we might get some others join in. I have tried 2 brands. My oncologist gave me Teva and I had a few hot flushes nothing else. My GP then prescribed a generic and the hot flushes were unbearable - I went from 5 or 6 a day to 20 or more - it was relentless. I spoke to my GP and she has specified Teva on my prescription. From all the discussions on here, I'm not sure if any one brand is better - it might be a case of finding the right one for you. Have you spoken to your GP? It might be worth ruling out anything else. My breast clinic have just launched a sort of menopause clinic - the gynaecology department staff it and the BCNs handle referral and you can go to discuss hormone therapy side effects. It might seem daft but I hadn't even thought that gynaecology would be the experts on this. It might be worth seeing if your unit run something similar or if they can refer you to someone. It's easy to think we should just grin and bear these side effects, but actually they can be draining and if it's something simple like changing brand that could fix them then worth investigating! Hope you can find some answers! R

Posts.Title: Radio active dye during lymph node removal

Posts.Content: Hi Rach1969 I don't want to worry you but I think you should speak to someone about this as soon as you can - it could be a blood clot. Try speaking to your oncology line tomorrow. If it is a clot it can be treated and they can give you a PICC or Hickman line. It isn't like a DVT but needs to be treated. I developed a blood clot after my 3rd EC with symptoms just like yours - I didn't have any redness or swelling but couldn't straighten my arm. I mentioned it to my oncologist who sent me for a vascular ultrasound scan - the radiologist described it as feeling like you have a tight string in your arm. It might not be, but best to check it out - until you get the all clear, avoid massaging it or putting strain on that arm but don't keep it still - that was the advice I was given by haematology. Hope it's soon sorted R

Posts.Title: Being fit and well is such a long way off

Posts.Content: Hi EJM60 Thanks - it's helpful to hear from someone else with similar problems - yours are more extensive than mine - you've really been through it. My shoulder was injured many many years ago and I think that's not helped. I did my exercises religiously after my operation and all through radiotherapy and now - I'm sure they have helped, I just have to accept it's going to take me time. Unfortunately radiotherapy just tightens everything up - you notice it happening. I took paracetamol and ibuprofen before my first radiotherapy but it didn't help - they abandoned the session, got an oncologist who prescribed me diclafenac, then tried again later. I didn't find it did much for my pain but it's anti-inflammatory and was just enough to allow me to get in to position. Hopefully your amitriptyline will do the trick. Mostly, the sessions are much shorter than the planning - they take images every so often so that takes a bit longer but they should be able to tell you which sessions that'll be. Tell them if you're struggling - my experience was that they are so rushed and 'technical' that they don't always have the people skills you'd like! They used to tell me over the intercom "you can take your arms down now" but I physically couldn't, I needed help and had to wait for them to come in. I'm not on any painkillers at the moment other than over the counter - I'm going to go to my GP and see what they can do. One thing my physio suggested yesterday was the Pink Ribbon programme. She knows I'm really keen to get back to some exercise and suggested I look for a trainer in my area. I don't know if that would be helpful for you after radiotherapy - it's pilates specifically designed for post breast cancer patients. I hope the radiotherapy goes well for you! R

Everyone is different but I think, generally it's not a gruelling treatment - I know people who've had it at 8.30am then gone into work every day. It's understandable you have down days - the waiting is the worst! Hopefully the down days will soon become moments.  This is a great place to come when you're down or fed up or want some advice! Take care R

I had an appointment today and was hoping he'd say everything was fine and I could stop the antibiotics, then I would have discussed the dog ear. Asked me why I wasn't having a reconstruction - because I don't want one - but you're young - yes - Well, (shrug) it's your decision - yes it is, thank you. Had a quick look at seroma and said - you don't need antibiotics just finish the course. That's it just go away and you only need to come back for your mammogram. So I explained that I had been discussing other things with my consultant and he said - well, he's not available today. I said that was fine, but I didn't know what to do about them and he just looked at me and said nothing. So I said I guess I'll contact the nurses if I need to and he nodded. It feels like a disappointing last appointment. I wasn't expecting a brass band or anything but I don't know why he felt he could question my reconstruction decision but then not help me with my questions. I feel like I've just been told I'm being a nuisance and been left to deal with the residual fluid and dog ear by myself. Posts.Content: Hi Hetty50 I think you might mean a product called Nanogen. This is the original product marketed at men with thinning hair. It is a like a pepperpot and it contains tiny fibres that you sprinkle in amongst your hair then spray with the accompanying hairspray (actually any "wet" hairspray will do and is much cheaper - not anything like Elnett though which is a dry spray) The fibres are a bit like the fibres in mascara and mimic the look of hair. There are a lot of other similar products now and a quick google should find them - they are different to a hair powder though although the packaging is the same so make sure you are buying something that has fibres in and is specifically for thinning hair. A word of caution - your scalp will be very sensitive so I'd give it a test run at home first so you can wash it out if you need to Good luck R

Posts.Content: Hi Aspen Welcome. Glad to see you have found the chemo club thread. Did you have a look at the first page? There is a link to some helpful things to take with you etc. Everyone reacts differently, but to reassure you - the majority of people with no underlying health conditions cope very well with chemo - I couldn't work because of the infection risk but I went running, met up with friends, did some house projects. Often you need to take it easy because of the risk of picking up infections - so no swimming, gardening for example - rather than that you physically can't manage it.  You could think about having a plan B - someone to call on if you can't pick up your son from school etc. It is usually the first week that is the worst and many people feel as normal weeks 2 and 3. There is a cumulative affect though so you may get a little more tired as the cycles go on. I had a little look at your profile - how is your son managing? If you need any help with that then there is some information about talking to children here but you could also give the helpline a call if you feel you want something more specific.  0808 808 00 00 open Monday to Friday 9am -8pm Hope the first chemo goes well - and all the Christmas prep, of course R

Posts.Content: Hi QuietRose Sorry you are experiencing this. I do think the 2nd round of chemo is hard - you know what to expect but it sort of hits home what you are going through.  I had a Hickman line for half my chemo - seeing the tubes hanging out of my chest every day was difficult and being able to feel it under my skin used to make me feel a bit ill - I'm quite squeamish. I could also sometimes feel the drugs pulsing into my neck - I got used to it though. Your feeling that it is wrong - do you think you'd like to talk to someone about that? You might find that this feeling goes away, but if it doesn't you will have an added worry every Thursday and Friday - an extra battle you don't need. No-ones body can fight cancer by itself - chemo can be tough but it is helping you. I have just finished my treatment but to begin with I felt a huge sense of failure - I'm quite a perfectionist and cancer is about as far away from perfect as you can be. I felt that I would never be able to look at my life as successful, because I'd had cancer and let myself and everyone else down. I don't feel like that now, but I had to take the time to deal with it - I had a couple of wobbles - wouldn't sign my chemo consent at first and then wouldn't have treatment my first session. It was probably fear and wanting to be in control. We all have our own internal hurdles to get over - it does take over your life so it makes sense that we would have a huge range of personal reactions to it. Have you told anyone from your team what you're feeling? How about your BCN? You might find s/he has come across it before. If not, what about giving the Macmillan helpline a call? Hopefully this will be something that will pass, but try to recognise it as a side effect that can be treated just like nausea. Hope round 3 is easier for you! R

Posts.Content: Hi Lobdobs My consultant drew me some pictures showing how they give radiotherapy to the left side. They go at a tangent to avoid the heart, though this can 'clip' the lung (his words) I think he said it was 3% of the lung. As AntsNest says, they will get you to hold your breath to lift your chest away from your heart so it is missed entirely. Posts.Content: Hi SpicedTea this is a little late as your appointment is tomorrow, but.... I have mentioned before that I have decided against reconstruction so can't offer anything there but I had an awful experience with the plastic surgeon so thought I'd tell you what I would do differently. If at all possible take someone with you - I didn't and wished I had (only time I've felt I needed someone there) Write questions down before you go but I'd also have pen and paper at the ready when you go in to jot down questions that occur - my consultation was very much a rehearsed presentation/performance that I was not expected to interrupt - when I tried to ask a question, he continued to speak over me!! If you want to discuss anything you've researched/read - have it with you - I was dismissed with a wave of the hand a couple of times and ended up taking the questions to my breast surgeon instead who answered them without hesitation. A lot of my questions were about recovery, recurrence, symmetry etc and he just did not want to discuss those things. Challenge them there and then and ask for a referral to someone else if you need to. I am confident that I would have decided against recon anyway but the surgeon influenced me negatively without a doubt. At the end of the consultation he said "So what do you think?" and I said "After speaking to you I think there's no way I want plastic surgery" and he waved his hand again and said "well that's up to you". I discussed all this with my BCN and told her I couldn't let him make me a breast while I was unconscious - it would increase my anxiety around the operation far too much. She completely understood that it was a trust issue and that I needed someone who I felt was in tune with my thinking. Anyway - don't mean that to worry you unduly - some people clearly find his approach adorable or he wouldn't have any patients. Hopefully your surgeon will be much more to your liking! The best advice I was given was by a friend who has had an LD flap plus implant then implant reduction and nipple reconstruction. Remember that they like doing surgeries, they do them all the time and they probably get bored by routine procedures - they will always want to try out new things and recommend future "fixes" Probably a little true I have my psychological assessment tomorrow for not wanting reconstruction - I'll think of you Good luck! R

Posts.Title: Flu jab and chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Jenniecros Sorry to hear you are suffering in this way. Has anyone given you any indication of how much improvement hormone therapy will give you in terms of % decrease in risk of recurrence? I'm sure that if your oncologist has recommended this as a course of action, then it's probably not increasing your risk over 3 months. Have you tried switching brands? Some people find some relief from symptoms that way, though any professionals I have spoken to tell me there is no reason this should be the case, but it works for a lot of us. Also, getting used to the lack of oestrogen can take time, though I completely understand you not wanting to continue with those side effects. Even if you haven't been through menopause yet, there are other options like Zoladex injections with an aromatase inhibitor (AIs are what they will give you post-menopause) or ovary removal. Do remember that people only post on here when they have problems - there are plenty of women taking these drugs with few or no side effects. I don't know if you've seen this other, similar thread  running at the moment? You might find some useful info there. Hopefully there will be a suitable solution for you! R

Posts.Content: Hi Scaredgirl34 Hopefully you are feeling a bit better now the sun is up and you can call your BCN. All sorts of things happen to your body after surgery - it's a very long process of healing and it takes months and months to settle down properly. You are, presumably, worried that it's recurrence? Wouldn't that have shown up on your mammogram and ultrasound too? This is a difficult process that we go through - learning to trust our bodies again. We all panic at the slightest thing - and in some ways that is a good thing (I put off getting my breast checked out because I was so certain it was yet another cyst) but when it is causing stress and worry, it can take over our thoughts a little and impact on our life more than we would like. Those of us who have been where you are, can tell you that it gets easier but it can be hard to entertain that idea while you are going through it. I couldn't have imagined a day when cancer wasn't on my mind the minute I woke up. Lots of people here assured me I would move on - and I have, but I wasn't convinced at the time. So what I am trying to say is - I am sure that there is a simple explanation for what you can feel, but it is natural to be worried at the stage you are at. In time, you will worry less. Hopefully your BCN has some reassurance for you - let us know how you get on R

Posts.Content: Hi Jillyp1210 I can't imagine how you must be feeling - these things are hard enough to deal with when they are part of the plan. I am assuming they left the skin in place so you could have an implant further down the line? Even if not, don't worry as that remains an option for you later - I think someone on here said they had one 18 months after treatment. I am taking a guess that you are still in hospital? I am pretty sure they will talk to you about your next step either now or at your check up - I chose a mastectomy and they still kept telling me I could have reconstruction, so they will get a new plan with you. Now for the practicalities - as  Kacang said, they should give you a softie for now - they are pretty basic - a beige triangle which comes in small medium or large - but they should combine them until they find your size and your BCN should help with that. Don't worry - I imagined mine falling out, getting mishapen, all sorts but actually I haven't even been for my prosthesis fitting yet and surgery was 4 months ago. I just shove the softie in and go. I also would recommend a pre-form cup as it disguises any uneven size issues (mine were pretty uneven before anyway) I think it probably varies depending on where you are but I got very little support from my BCN regarding bras. You will need your post surgery bra for now - if you had one already it's probably fine - you want softness, support and some compression the first couple of weeks. I'll put some links in for you re bras at the end. You are entitled to a silicone prosthesis on the nhs - you should get an appointment for a fitting either at your hospital or somewhere still local. Like I said, I haven't had mine yet but my BCN assures me you just know when you've found the right one - I am imagining it very much like Harry Potter in the wand shop, but might be disappointed. The mastectomy bras are pocketed so you slot the prosthesis or softie in the pocket. Actually, as time has gone on, I have thought more that I will prefer the softie or a knitted knocker as Kacang says. I am knitting myself one in beautiful yarn so that I love it and it gives me some control.  Don't worry about looking at your 'chest' (we need a better name for it) take your time. My surgeon told me not to look at it straight away. It changes as time goes by anyway. First - here is a link with photos of mastectomies - naked and in clothes - it's very much about choosing a mastectomy but may help reassure in terms of looks. http://breastfree.org/ You have the amoena link already - I think they do the best in terms of size and variety but there are more accessible ones too. Debenhams do a large range and also stock amoena m.debenhams.com/.../post surgery bras M+S do a small range - I am linking to one I bought - it is completely lined so the elastic is covered which makes it more comfortable - I wore it for rads and it didn't irritate at all www.marksandspencer.com/.../p22354463 I've just seen they sell foam breast forms too for £18 so if you don't like your softie... Here's the knitted knockers site if you want to request one (if you want to knit one-yell. Kacang passed the patterns on so one of us can give you those) www.knittedknockersuk.com/ Hope you are recovering well surgery wise - I am happy to send you masses of links etc if you want them or answer questions - the bra issue was and still is massive for me - we'll all be beside you through this - you will get to where you want to be! Sending hugs R

Posts.Content: Hi Rach1969 Dry itchy scalp can be caused by lots of things - allergies/sensitivities to products, stress, heat, sweat sitting on the scalp for too long, as well as things like dandruff, eczema, psoriasis etc I don't know how long ago your chemo stopped but a general rule of thumb with the skin is to give 6 months for things to settle and calm down. If the itchiness isn't constant then it could just be that it is getting stimulated when you wash it - too much scrubbing or water too hot? If your GP thinks you have a scalp condition like psoriasis etc then the T-gel is a good option as it is designed to treat those things. You could think about your conditioner and styling products - if you are still using the same ones then maybe go without them for a few washes and see if things change. (Not easy, I know) Finally, I'll share my experience. I've had itchy flaky scalp since my teens and have been a hairdresser for years - used T-gel, prescription coal tar shampoo, all the shampoos marketed for dandruff, organic shampoos, expensive shampoos, cheap shampoos, baby shampoos etc etc nothing helped Someone told me to try Moogoo products and I didn't even bother looking at them for about a year - then things got so bad I just couldn't cope so I gave them a try and they've worked for me. That's all I use now and a few styling products that don't cause me problems (trial and error with that) However, that isn't a guarantee they'll work for you - it really depends on what is causing the problem. Hope you find a solution R

Posts.Title: I still have a large seroma 5 months after my surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Resilent Welcome to the online community. I'm not sure if Shartom is still using the site, so thought I would reply instead. My seroma got infected last year with a sore throat bacteria. It took some doing to get rid of the infection - lots of draining - twice a week at the hospital. I also developed an abscess at one point.  The problem with seroma's - as you will see from the other posts, is that they tend to refill as soon as they are drained so lots of surgeons seem to prefer not to drain them. If they get infected though, it's very difficult to deal with the infection as there are no blood vessels etc in the fluid, so no way for antibiotics to get there efficiently. In this situation it becomes more important to have it drained to get rid of the infection. That's how my surgeon explained it to me - (except he used a really really extended metaphor about an island in the sea :)  ) My GP told me I was "incredibly unfortunate" to have an infection in the seroma so I don't think it's very common. I don't know anything about the Biozorb, I'm afraid but the fluid from a seroma is usually clear yellow - well, if there's not a problem. It looks like pee, basically. If it's a more opaque yellow then could it be pus? Some of that drained out when mine was infected. Sorry I'm not more help - maybe someone else will be able to reply with a bit more info - there are quite a few technical problems today so hopefully there will be more replies when they are sorted. Take care R

Posts.Content: Hi commoner I meant to reply to your post when it first went up but got distracted - sorry! You've had loads of helpful advice and have settled on your decision which is great. I was in the same situation as you just over a year ago and I appreciate what you are going through - it's a hard decision. I just wanted to let you know that I worried so much about how a prosthetic would feel - whether it would ride up when I went running, if it would be obvious because it moved differently to my other breast - how it would feel to sleep on my front with only one breast - oh so many small but frightening questions. What happened is that I knitted myself a knitted knocker and took nearly a year to get round to getting my prosthesis. I've only worn it once or twice - they aren't too much of a faff - just a quick wash with soapy water at night - I just prefer my knitted knocker. I go running with either my knitted knocker or the post-op softie they give you - a sports bra keeps them in placel - M+S do a good mastectomy one - as do others, I'm sure. Now, I don't even notice that only one breast is real - sometimes I have to have a sneaky feel when I'm out, because I can't remember if I put it on or not! I did just want to mention about double mastectomy because you said you had considered it. I asked for both breasts to be removed with no reconstruction. My surgeon wasn't keen and preferred me to wait until after the initial surgery to see how I felt. I got approved for it but then changed my mind. My surgeon has agreed to keep it as an option for me later if I want it. So - although it is a hard decision and you are happy that you are making the right one - it doesn't have to be a final decision and if you decide in time, that you want a bilateral or you want a reconstruction - they may still be options for you. Glad you are feeling better about it! R

Posts.Content: Hi volvox167 I just wanted to reply with something which I hope won't seem negative - it really isn't meant to be. I was/am very like you. I would say it took me a year to recover physically and there are still some things - swimming for example - that I think are still beyond my current capabilities. I had chemo, mastectomy, node clearance and radiotherapy. Really, the reason for explaining my experience is that I had the simplest surgery because I was very focused on getting back to work and to running, but have still struggled. I don't wish I had chosen a different option - I am fine with my flat side (though it took time) but I wouldn't ever recommend it to someone as an easier option because everyone is different - I can have mx and have problems, others have reconstruction and have no problems. It is a factor to consider, of course, but it's not a guarantee that things will be easier. I am sure you are more sensible than me (that's not hard) and your recovery will hopefully be quick. I like the Michael Jordan quote: "I’ve missed more than 9000 shots in my career. I’ve lost almost 300 games. 26 times, I’ve been trusted to take the game winning shot and missed. Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hi I have, for now, given up alcohol (not entirely - I'll raise a glass when apropriate) because there is a proven link with certain cancers including breast cancer. None of the other popular ideas around food have been proven so I will bear them in mind but not cut them out of my diet. I am 48 - since I left home at 19 I have eaten very healthily and for the last 15/20 years I have avoided processed food and make everything myself. I don't eat refined sugar or high sugar foods (high carb foods) I aim for at least 7 fruit/veg a day, I never have meat more than once in a day and I often have meat-free days, I avoid too much red meat, I drink plain water during the day, I don't like dairy but have a portion a day as I have osteopenia, I eat 'superfoods' every day and vary my diet as much as possible to get plenty of anti-oxidants and the full range of vitamins, minerals and nutrients necessary for good health. Got cancer though! That's kind of why I find it hard to believe diet is the answer - I was never eating that way to avoid cancer, it was about feeling well and having the energy for my lifestyle and I will continue to eat that way (during chemo was a different matter) but I know it's not a good diet that will make the difference for me. We know that all our cancers are different, our lives are different, our genes are different so it's possible our solutions are going to be different too. In much the same way that hormone therapy is a treatment for some breast cancer, maybe dietary changes are relevant for certain breast cancers. Ultimately, I think we need to do the things that resonate with us and that we are comfortable with. There's no point avoiding recurrence and secondaries if you are going to resent every mouthful you eat for the next 30 years never knowing for sure whether it's working -  it's a balance. R

Posts.Content: Hi Sk18 I see you've had a reply in the under 50's group but wanted to bump you up the list a bit here. As toxophilite says, this is a busier group and sometimes posts slip down the list a bit and don't get seen. I was ER+ Her2- and I had the EC/T regime. The drugs are prescribed depending on individual circumstances so although we may think our diagnoses are the same, there can be subtle differences to oncologists that lead them to a different drug regime.  I had my chemo by infusion which generally took about an hour and a half for the EC. I did get them to slow the C bit down though because it gave me a bad headache. It's a frightening thing to go through and it's important that you have confidence in your team. You could ask them about the speed of the injections - there might be a good reason for it to be different - or you could ask in our Ask a Nurse section. They are very knowledgeable and aim to reply in 2 working days. Just out of curiosity, I wondered if you are in the UK? We have people here from all over the world and things can be quite different in different countries. I hope that chemo is being kind to you and you are not experiencing too many side effects. You might want to take a look at our breast cancer chemo club thread. It's a place for everyone going through treatment to share their experiences - it can be a great support and source of information.  Take care R

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - week 3 of 3

Posts.Content: Hi May day No advice as such - I was prescribed Pyridoxine too but found it did little. My last chemo was in September 16 and it was probably January/February before my hands were fit for purpose and my feet took longer - they still flair up a bit now but I can cope with them. Flip flops are a no-go but walking is OK when I get going. I have found that the stumbling, pain, puppet-walk thing gets better with exercise - days I am at home it gets worse. I try for at least 20 minutes of walking a day. I'm still not confident in normal shoes and trip quite a bit so I stick to trainers when possible. The PN was worse in my hands but they healed faster and I think it's because they are used more. The physio told me to thread paperclips and make pastry to re-build the nerves - little movements to make the nerves re-grow. So, I guess the same applies to our feet - using them more will help the nerves. I am also on amitritilyn for other nerve problems in my surgery arm - the GP had a good chat about the options with me. I think a visit to yours should get you somewhere! Fingers crossed! R

Posts.Content: Hi jb63 that is quite a bit of medication. My treatment finished in December 2016 - last chemo was September 2016 - I still have a bit of peripheral neuropathy as well as nerve pain in my arm from the ANC and tendon inflammation in my wrist. I have just gone back to work - I've been off 2 years. I'm still not able to do everything I used to at work. Not all of us bounce back the way we think we will, but you will get there. You could speak to your oncologist about the Letrozole - some people find different brands better but there are also other AIs they can give you. It is also possible to go onto Tamoxifen - that works for pre and post menopause - the AIs are a more recent treatment and research has shown benefits to switching to them post menopause but if they are ruining your quality of life then you might want to consider your options - or at least discuss it. Hang on to the positive of the good nights sleep from the amitriptilyn - I take it for my nerve pain and have never slept so well in my life! It is still quite soon after your treatment - you are still in recovery, so be kind to yourself - don't rush back to work. Hope you find some relief from the pain R

Posts.Title: Was this the start?

Posts.Content: Hi wombat.23 It's a tough one - we are going to dwell on something - is it better to dwell on the what if's of the past or the future? I first went to the breast clinic in 2004 - reassured it was a cyst (it was) and told I had 10 cysts in one breast, 15 in the other. I was told to keep checking for changes - I did but probably got complacent. February this year, the largest cyst was painful and felt harder - well no prizes for guessing why! It was 52mm, there was a second one and it's gone to lymph nodes I have spent time chastising myself but have forgiven myself now. One thing I am able to remind myself is that at my first appointment in February, my consultant examined me and said - wow they are really lumpy breasts! - he told me he couldn't  feel a definite lump but as it was lumpy he sent me for mammogram - it was fairly clear from that. Breast cancer is one of the few cancers that we are able to detect ourselves so that puts undue pressure on us to do so and to feel guilty when we don't. However, we are not great at finding them - the drive to check your breasts every month did little to increase detection, doctors miss them, radiographers miss them, consultants miss them - and they are trained and experienced at finding them. Of course you might have found it earlier, but imagine if you didn't find it when you did - imagine finding it in 6 months time and wishing you had found it now. I like to take comfort in cliches - if life gives you lemons etc. The overwhelming characteristic about cancer is that it is random - we didn't ask for it or cause it and we don't deserve it.  I prefer to look ahead - this is what I have - what can I do to minimise my risk of recurrence and secondaries - I might be able to do something about that - I can't do anything about the past. Crucially - try to forgive yourself because you did nothing wrong. Hope you are soon feeling less cross with yourself! R

Posts.Title: Mobility issues and coordination since finishing treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Ruthie63 It's a tough one - I never had to make that choice. Hopefully you have some idea of what you want to do. When I was first diagnosed, I told my consultant that I was happy to have whatever treatment would give me the best outcome and have not asked for statistics - I had 2 tumours, grade 2, lymph node involvement so have had 8 rounds of chemo, mastectomy and node clearance - radiotherapy next! If they advised me to do the whole thing again - I probably would. That's easy to say, though as I have no underlying health issues and have fared quite well through treatment.  What I do have is a cousin with multiple severe disabilities - we grew up together and I have watched him go through countless treatments and survive sometimes against the odds. He is an inspiration to me and I can tell myself that what is happening to me is nothing to what he has been through and if he gets up and gets on with it every day, so will I. This is to say that we are all different - different lives, attitudes and experiences so only you will know the best thing for you.  What I would say is if you are otherwise fit and well, chemo may be very manageable for you - it was for me. I wish you all the best with making this difficult decision! R

Posts.Content: Hi JustLittleMe Not a huge amount of help as I haven't made it back to work yet - I teach in FE but on zero hours contract so no phased return. I've only managed a couple of sessions as first I broke my arm and now I have an infection which has knocked me sideways - my daughter teases me that I don't really want to go back to work - maybe there is some truth in that. Anyway - the couple of sessions I did do, I felt fine- nowhere near as bad as I had imagined! I appreciate if you are in a school, these probably aren't options you have, but the main message is I don't think it'll be as hard as you think - once you step back in it's second nature! Posts.Title: Back to work anxiety

Posts.Content: Hi fairport May I give you a warm welcome to the online community. There is no need to apologise - we are here for everyone - my treatment finished nearly a year ago - I stick around and may still be here posting in another 6 years! We are a large friendly group who can understand how you feel - we have members who finished treatment a few years ago - maybe they will be along in a bit. Getting a cancer diagnosis is a traumatic event and different people take different lengths of time to process it. Counselling can help - I won't suggest calling your BCN as you don't seem to have a rapport with them - how about your GP? They can refer you to someone who has experience with this. You say you can't find any good news but you are 7 years on and that is a strong positive. Emotionally you may be struggling, but just as you had treatment for the physical symptoms of cancer, you can have treatment for the psychological ones too. Now, there is a good article that one of our champs - Kacang - has as her signature. I'm sure she won't mind me stealing it for you! It's here.  It's quite long but will hopefully be useful and show you that you are not alone feeling as you do. We also have a Life after cancer  group if you are looking for people in a similar position - but we are more than happy to have you in this group. Hopefully you'll get some more advice along soon! R

Posts.Content: Hi Just want to throw a terrible thing in to the mix - try crying! :) My GP did give me the R1/R2 - she was horrified at the cost, but basically I just walked in, showed her the website and said - "please can you prescribe me this" I was quite upset and listed the problems I'd had during chemo and the nerve pain I was experiencing after surgery and told her I thought I had been through enough and didn't want to have to contend with burnt or blistered skin if there was a way I could avoid that. She did say she didn't think it was approved but she was just going to prescribe it anyway. It's worth a shot - but as others have said - lots of women use other creams with success - unless they do proper trials on it how will we know if it's the cream or we are just lucky. Posts.Title: Chemotherapy & vile chemical taste in mouth

Posts.Content: Hi Bee363 It's all so confusing and worrying at first, isn't it? The first thing I would say is that I am sure you are in excellent hands. They are really good at treating breast cancer and will be working towards the best plan for you!  You probably won't be able to stop your brain working overtime until your plan is in place. I'm sure you'll feel better after your appointment next week. I'll just share a little of my story in case it reassures you! Diagnosed in February- the original plan was chemo to shrink my (quite large) tumor then lumpectomy surgery. The day before my chemo was due to start I was told there was probably another tumour in the same breast and I tipped up for my first chemo knowing I would now need a mastectomy. I refused to have my chemo - insisted on re-negotiating my treatment plan, got handled very gently by the chemo nurses and the oncologist and finally agreed to return for chemo the next day and follow the original plan because that was the best chance at that point of stopping the cancer spreading! Had all the information been available at the start, they would have recommended surgery first but that was just not how it happened! In hindsight - they were right of course and since researching and speaking more calmy to my doctors I can see that I was just scared because it was all happening so fast! There is no reason my outcome should be any different even though my treatment feels like the wrong way round to me. You can't help worrying but make sure you shove some positivity in there too - look around the posts on here - there are lots of inspiring people and outcomes! Whatever your plan, you will accept and adjust and you will be feeling so much calmer soon - it's hard when things move fast but how fantastic that they do! Good luck with the plan and the treatment and hoping it doesn't seem too long till your appointment! R

Posts.Title: Lots of questions!

Posts.Content: Hi badgerbam Welcome - sorry to hear about your mum. I hope she is doing well. I was also told repeatedly that it wasn't in my lymph nodes but then told it was after sentinel node biopsy. It was a massive shock but doesn't necessarily mean it has spread. The lymph nodes are meant to catch intruders and stop them spreading so hopefully they have done their job! I had a CT scan, bone scan and MRI as part of my diagnosis before treatment but I knew I was having chemo from day one. These tests are standard at my hospital - it gives a clear picture of your overall health as much as checking it hasn't spread - having the tests doesn't mean they think it has spread! My treatment wasn't the same as I had chemo first then a mastectomy so they did a node clearance along with the mastectomy. I know different hospitals do things differently and other people will come along with their experiences but my hospital remove nodes if it has spread and advise radiotherapy if it is in 3 or more nodes. The situation you all find yourself in is horrible - it's hard to believe but once your mum has been given a treatment plan it gets a lot easier. I finished treatment in December last year - it took nearly a year and when I look back, sometimes I can't believe it happened - your mum and you will get through this one day at a time. I hope your mum gets her plan soon and you can both start to be a little less anxious. R

Posts.Title: Received Lumpectomy Results, 2 sentinel nodes have cancer - what happens...

Posts.Content: Hi - just wanted to add to what NickF mentioned. I think there will be progress on the node clearance front but for anyone having neo-adjuvant chemo before the nodes are looked at - there is no way of knowing for certain how many had cancer cells before chemo if you only examine them after chemo - that's why mine were removed and rads recommended. Personally, I'd rather be on the safe side and lymphoedema risk is about 20 % which were odds I was willing to take. R

So - don't ruin the next 2 weeks worrying - hopefully it will be something benign. All the worrying in the world won't change things, it's just draining! Distract yourself and keep busy! We will all keep our fingers crossed for you - let us know your results. R

Posts.Title: Stopping Scars From Drying Out

Posts.Content: Hi Haysie Sorry to hear you've had this shock - it takes time to get our heads around things and then to find changes suddenly forced on us can be frightening! Don't panic too much about chemo. A lot of people find it very do-able and stay well. It isn't something we'd ever recommend but it also isn't anything like you are probably imagining.  Lots of people manage to work through it and carry on an active life.  I can understand preferring to have the surgery first - knowing the tumour is still there can be difficult but there are a few positives - you will be scanned part way through treatment so you will have an idea of how well the chemo is working  you will be doing chemo when you are at your fittest - my surgery knocked me for six - if I had felt like that before I started chemo, I don't think I'd have handled it so well. If the tumour is smaller, greater chance of clear margins You should be well looked after during chemo - I found everyone in the unit very kind and understanding - I had a few wobbles. My advice would be - take all the drugs they offer you and feed back very clearly any side effects. They really don't want you to suffer in silence and they have many options - sometimes they don't bring out the big guns (more expensive guns) unless they know they need to, so let them know exactly how you are coping.  And - keep on top of your hygiene and temperature and call them when you need to - even if you think it's nothing and it's the middle of the night. They really don't mind. Good luck with it - let us know how you are getting on. R

Posts.Title: Neuropathy getting worse

Posts.Content: Hi Sue63 I had a seroma drained yesterday (surgery was just over 4 months ago and it came up a week ago) but I didn't have reconstruction. Posts.Title: 12 day after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Ansti A warm welcome to the online community. Though none of us would choose to find ourseves here, it is a friendly place with lots of support from people who completely understand. It is amazing how much better you can feel by having some space to let it all out! I always felt my medical team were drip feeding me to some extent - I think they sometimes try not to overwhelm us. It is true that things may change after your mastectomy but I wanted to reassure you that many of us handle chemo very well. It isn't a breeze exactly but is very do-able.  As you are finding - the waiting and the not knowing is hard - it really is the worst bit. Once you do get the results and know what your treatment plan is, you will feel better and can just take it one day at a time till one day it will be over. I'm glad writing it all down has helped - if you do find you have any questions - ask away - there is always someone around to help!! Let us know how it goes R
Posts.Title: Surgery in 10 days, then .... no idea

Posts.Content: Hi Mamma55 I am in the opposite position to you - I have breast cancer and my (grown up) daughter is the only family nearby and so has to do all the helping! She also had a couple of holidays booked and I would have felt terrible if she cancelled them! I feel that cancer has taken enough from me, I don't want it to start robbing my family too! We arranged for my mum to stay when she was away at "chemo time" so that she could relax on holiday and she messaged me every day. I felt so much better seeing the pictures she sent me and knowing she was getting a break. You say your daughter will have other family around her so she will be looked after and you will be able to be there the next time. It is hard when you want to help and are not allowed - I am a very stubborn and self sufficient person and it has taken time (diagnosed in February) for me to let anyone help let alone for me to ask for help!! I go to my hospital appointments by myself - my daughter comes near the end of chemo with a nice coffee for me! Your daughter may soften in time but as long as she knows you are there and knows she can ask for help, then you are being the support she needs! You will worry, of course but try to enjoy your holiday and maybe you will be able to give some practical help when you get back! R

Posts.Title: What do you call yours?

Posts.Content: Hi GrandmaStar Anastrozole is one of the aromatase inhibitors. They work in a slightly different way to Tamoxifen, though the end result is the same - they stop your cells from taking up oestrogen. My oncologist explained it beautifully to me but, of course it just vanished when I left the room. They are used post-menopause instead of Tamoxifen and studies have shown improved survival stats for switching. They can cause bone thinning so you should be given a bone density scan before you start and then have them at intervals to check whether you need supplements to prevent that. I can't tell you any more than that as I am still on Tamoxifen, but I'm sure someone else will be along shortly to fill in the gaps! R

Posts.Content: Hi Beth567 A very warm welcome to the group. I'm not in exactly the same situation as you but I thought I'd reply as I might be able to reassure you while we wait for some others. There are a few of us here who have had mastectomies with or without delayed recon, but as Atty said it is a really busy group so sometimes posts can get a little lost. If we keep replying to you - we will keep bumping you to the top of the list and then your post will hopefully be seen by more people. I am a 34F - I'm not trying to compare breast sizes, just to give you an idea of the size of my breasts in relation to the rest of me. I had a single mastectomy in 2016 but the difference is I didn't want reconstruction and I am not BRCA positive. There were, and are, all sorts of reasons why I didn't want recon but some of it was to do with the size of my breasts and the impact that had on the choices I was offered. I ruled out an implant because the plastic surgeon told me that in my size the only option was a round one and it would have been hugely different to my other breast so I then would have needed another surgery on my other breast to match it up and I just couldn't face the thought of 2 surgeries and ending up with a pair of breasts nothing like mine.  I considered the DIEP but eventually decided against it - I had just been through 6 months of chemo and wanted the option with the quickest recovery. Anyway - that's all just some background, now I'll tell you how I have felt. In all honesty - I struggled at the beginning. I didn't want to look at my flat side at the same time as my remaining breast, I hated having to find the right solution to fill my bras - there were a whole load of clothes I couldn't wear - even though it was my choice, I was quite upset. Everyone on here was great and really helped me to come to terms with it and, in hindsight, it didn't take that long. I am quite fond of my scar now - and I sometimes have to have a sly check when I am out that I remembered to put something in there because I give it so little thought these days. What options have they offered you for the time before your reconstruction? Will they give you 2 silicone prostheses? Have you been shown them? They probably give the best shape and look most like a real breast - they also have a bit of weight to them so would maybe feel a bit better to you. Otherwise there are softies which they may give you for after surgery - just a beige triangle filled with stuffing. That was one of the worst bits for me - just the thought of this very medical looking thing that I had to keep washing and drying. Someone on here thankfully told me about knitted knockers - a charity which provides hand knitted breasts to BC patients - and gave me a pattern to knit one myself. Compared to the hospital softie, they are a thing of beauty and a much better shape. That is what I wear on a daily basis. One really important thing, I think is to find a bra you like. My chest is very flat so I need a much fuller cup than I would have worn before otherwise there is a gap on one side of my cleavage. You might find you are more comfortable with a different style bra until you have your reconstruction - it can make a big difference to your confidence, I think to feel that your breasts look right and that is down to the shape and style of the prosthesis and the bra. there are a few places that do mastectomy bra fittings. I went to John Lewis but some Debenhams stores do them, Marks and Spencer and possibly Bravissimo. My prosthesis fitter recommended them to me because of my struggle finding a mastectomy bra in my size and people on here have said that they will sew pockets into any bra. Sorry - I've gone on a bit and especially about bras, but getting the right one makes all the difference to how I feel. Let me know if you have any more questions.  R

It was something I discussed with my team when I was diagnosed in 2016, but eventually decided against it. If you're not BRCA positive, it often isn't offered to you outright but it's definitely something you should discuss with your surgeon. See what they say when you ask them - I always think it's good to have all the options on the table - for me, just knowing I could opt for that made it a little easier to deal with. I probably just wanted a bit of control over the whole situation, to be honest but that is a reasonable response to what we go through, I think. I wasn't able to have a lumpectomy as I had 3 tumours in the one breast so I was told it had to be mastectomy. It is true that statistically lumpectomies achieve the same outcome, but do remember medical people take comfort in numbers and facts whereas we wake in the middle of the night with a bunch of what ifs! Ultimately, this is your treatment and if you have an understanding surgeon then they should allow you to come to the decision that is right for you, regardless of the statistics. We are individuals and we all react differently and are satisfied with different outcomes. In the end I had a single mastectomy without reconstruction and I'm really content with that, but other people would be really unhappy with it. Was there anything in particular you wanted to know? Perhaps we can rustle up someone to help. Sorry to hear your anxiety is bad but I think you can forgive yourself - it's natural given what you are going through. If you haven't already, you can always see your GP if it's really bad - they are often very understanding about the issues around cancer. Lots of people here will tell you the anxiety fades with time - and it does. It's really difficult to believe while you are still going through it all, but there will be a day when you realise you are not as worried. We grow up trusting our bodies and a cancer diagnosis takes that away from us, and it takes time to build that trust back up. For now, one step at a time - right foot, left foot and repeat. We are all here for you whenever you need. Hopefully we'll get someone along who can help a bit more than me. R

Posts.Title: Issues after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi It is standard practice to test the lymph nodes. If they look clear on ultrasound then they will often do a biopsy later on once they have the results and know what they are dealing with - no point testing nodes randomly before they have diagnosed a lump. The way the lymph system works is that the nodes are a line of defence which are designed to stop things invading your body. That's why they get swollen when you are ill. Sometimes they will find cancer cells in the nodes but they have been trapped there and haven't travelled to the rest of the body. By the end of treatment I had had 16 lymph nodes tested and 3 of those had cancer cells in them. My treatment was designed to remove my tumour and treat my lymph nodes for any rogue cancer cells (radiotherapy) and treat my entire body for rogue cancer cells (chemotherapy). A year later, and I am considered to be currently free of cancer - there has been no evidence of spread. Each patient is different and the teams that treat them devise a plan to give the best outcome, and breast cancer has very very high success rates. It's natural that you will panic but try not to exhaust yourself with all the possibilities. I know some people feel reassured by investigating everything and being prepared for the worst. When your girlfriend gets her results, she will most likely see a consultant who will explain what everything means. If it turns out to be something other than cancer, there will probably still be a lot of information to take in. You could both start a list of questions that you want to ask so that you don't forget anything. It can also be useful to make notes or ask if you can record the conversation on your phone (I am presuming you will also go to the results appointment) The medical professionals do this day after day and they understand how we all feel and guide you through the process well. It is frightening but people will support you every step of the way. We are all here for you both as much as you need. R

Posts.Content: Hi Pointer - are you on hormone therapy? After surgery I had inflamed tendons in my wrist after surgery and we just couldn't get it to go away. My breast clinic physio told me that they are beginning to think there is a link between the hormone therapy and tendon issues. It certainly seems to come up now and again on here. Have you seen a breast cancer specialist physio? I'm thinking yes if you have been treated for cording. Any breaking of the skin can be a risk for lymphoedema but it's largely the infection risk that is a problem. It might be a good idea to discuss the lymphoedema with them. My tendon problem eventually stopped when I developed lymphoedema and was fitted for a sleeve. The physio thought it had probably been the lymphoedema causing the problem in the first place. I'm not remotely suggesting you have lymphoedema - I have rubbish veins and have always been a fluid type of person - I also had a seroma after surgery which was drained many times and my lymphoedema specialist blamed that - I think it was probably inevitable for me. But the risk is worrying you so  it might be worth having a discussion and checking for signs. You could also post in Ask about lymphoedema  where a specialist will get back to you in 2 working days. Beachwalker19 - they need to give you a line! Ask them to give you a PICC line or Hickman line or a port - you shouldn't have to go through that to have chemo. Have you had a vascular scan to see why they are having trouble? I have to admit, they struggle to get bloods from me these days - they tend to have to go into my hand. I got a Hickman line half-way through chemo - I don't know why they don't just fit a line at the beginning - it made everything so much easier. Fingers crossed you both get these things sorted out R

Posts.Title: how long after surgery could treatment begin

Posts.Content: Hi Beth567 I can understand you dreading waiting for reconstruction but I definitely think that, as you say, it will be better in the long term. They usually advise you wear a bra straight after surgery - something soft, no underwire and front fastening is easier. You can get them from the specialist online shops like Amoena and Nicola Jane. You will probably be told to wear it overnight as well so best to get a couple so you can wash them. They normally give you a softie or two to leave with and advise you don't wear anything else for a while (I think it was 6 weeks but I can't remember) The pain isn't massive for a mastectomy - I took paracetamol for 2 days. You will be given exercises to do to maintain the movement in your arm and shoulder and you start them the day after surgery usually. Let's think - I was probably back in a normal bra about 4 weeks after surgery - I've given up on underwires though because they irritate my node clearance scar - your scar might be shorter. I think I would have waited longer to wear an underwire. As for the prosthesis - you have to have a fitting to get the right one so hopefully that will be sorted out for you after the surgery - I actually waited nearly a year for mine because I was a bit reluctant to get one (I don't know why), so I don't really know how soon you can wear one - pretty soon though I'd think. There is a website called breastfree where you can see photos of real women with mastectomies with and without clothes. I wasn't sure whether to tell you about it as it is a little bit pro-flat, but if you don't mind ignoring their anti-recon stance - the pictures are really good and I found it helpful to see what it was going to look like. Of course this is a really difficult decision for you to make - if there's anything else I can help with - let me know! R
Posts.Title: Total mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Jackproc Welcome to the online community. It must be quite a shock for your girlfriend and you to be dealing with this news and waiting for results is just awful.  Since you mention histology, I presume your girlfriend had a biopsy? In which case she most likely had an ultrasound. Mammograms show up areas of concern, ultrasounds give a better idea of what sort of tissue has shown up in the mammogram and then the biopsy identifies exactly what the cells are.  There are some things to think about to help reassure you IF it turns out to be cancer: - breast cancer is very treatable and has successful outcomes for about 90% of people - there are many of us here who have been through treatment and are now getting on with our lives. results give ideas about the aggressiveness of a tumour but that refers to how fast it is growing, not whether it has spread Malignant doesn't necessarily mean it has spread - it has the potential to but may not have had the opportunity or the time to. If it is found to be a form of breast cancer, then your girlfriend will be given further tests and biopsies to see if it has spread and to find the best method of treating it. It is a very worrying time for you both and a shock particularly as she is so young. There is a link to some information on breast cancer here and specifically about tests and diagnosis here. Some people like to research and know as much as possible before their results, others prefer to not know and hear everything from the medical team. Sometimes a bit of both works. One thing we normally would advise is to stay away from Dr Google - that can lead to some very terrifying and untrue information.  If you do want to research - I am thinking that maybe you do as you have reached out to us - then stick to the reputable sites - Macmillan, obviously, Cancer Research UK, Breast Cancer Care, Breast Cancer Now  Try to distract yourself, and your girlfriend until the results appointment. It isn't easy, but it can be so overwhelming and it can help to have lots of things to do so that you don't get consumed by "what ifs" We will all be thinking of you both - please let us know how she gets on R

Posts.Content: Hi all I don't have a garden - just a tiny balcony on which I try to grow various things very unsuccessfully! I thought I'd share a different perspective on the slug/pests problem. My daughter has always been a gentle soul - when she inevitably had head lice as a child, I used to comb them from her hair while she sat there in tears because I was killing them, and then we had to bury them and say a few words!!!! Anyway, being a couple of floors up, I don't get slugs and snails, but I once had a lovely display of geraniums which caterpillars turned to twigs in a day - I was furious and my daughter caught me flinging them all on to the ground below. After she called me a murderer, I tried to explain to her why I was doing it. Afterwards, her reply was - "but it's their food, you only want them to look at - why can't you share them?" It floored me and I didn't have a reply. Her simplistic solution was to just plant more of them, then we could all have some.  I know it doesn't work that way, but it did make me look at them less as "pests" and more as things I can try to co-exist with. My solution was to never grow geraniums again - not sure that's helping the caterpillars much :) I've been nursing a nasty cold these last few days so no exercise - I'm off to the park again in a bit to try a little walk. The 6 cygnets are now only 3 :(   Hoping some of them make it to adulthood!!! Have a good day everyone! R

Posts.Content: Hi OCRKate Just to echo what the others have said - I used to run 3 times a week and circuit train 3 times a week before breast cancer in 2016. I was told no swimming and no gym during chemo due to infection risk, but my team were more than happy for me to keep running. I should think the mud runs etc would be a no-no, though. I got too tired towards the end of the 6 months and also had a line in my chest which I figured got too sweaty (after a trip to the hospital with an infection that possibly came from the entry site of the line) I carried on walking as much as I could and did some resistance exercises at home. Check with your team, but they are usually OK for you to do as much as you can manage - it just needs to be germ-free. Wishing you well through chemo R

Posts.Content: Hi Peggysgirl Welcome! Hopefully you are feeling better now the day is up and running. You've had great advice already - I just wanted to tell you I was a little terrified of joining this site - it's quite far out of my comfort zone and my daughter was absolutely shocked when I told her. It's now 5 months since I finished my treatment and I'm still hanging around now and again. It has been a huge support for me and probably the most helpful thing I've come across during treatment. It really is a community and we will be here whenever you need us! I had node involvement after being repeatedly assured they were fine - I don't know why they do that - I guess they can't really tell for sure till they get them in the lab. I had all my nodes removed (and chemo and rads) and now I feel that it's gone and I'm in the same position as anyone else finishing treatment. It can be hard to stay positive and lots of us will identify with the feeling that it keeps getting worse, but you will get to a point where you have all the information and you make your way through treatment one day at a time. None of us will tell you this is easy, but it is very do-able and treatment is very effective. Being positive is the big picture - you are allowed to cry, to be angry but then step back and look at the positive. Good luck with the scan on Friday - let us know how it goes! R

Posts.Title: Just when I was trying to get back to normal

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic It's brave of you to post your feelings like that - does it feel good to have written them down? As you are probably realising - they are very normal feelings.  Before I say anything else - you were told you had cancer 4 weeks ago and you had surgery 3 days ago! You need to be kind to yourself and I would say that you should try to explain to your family that you need some time alone sometimes. There is a very big difference between being sad and being depressed. Your family are probably worried about you and want to help you. If you were depressed, no amount of jollying you along would help and is often detrimental as it makes people feel that they are failing because they can't "snap out of it". Given what you are going through, it is more likely that you are sad - but if you feel consistently low and it doesn't improve over the next couple of weeks, please seek some help. So - if you were to explain to your family that you are still an optimist, but you are feeling sad and need some time alone to process your thoughts, do you think they would be happier to give you some space? It shouldn't be all the time, but it isn't wrong! It also isn't wrong to cry in front of them and with them - they are going through a hard time too, and it can help to share emotions - you are not ruining their happiness. You've already had good advice about reasons not to worry, so I am going to tell you this - you will be happy again!  I am the same age as you and diagnosed in February - I left my lump for a while before I went to my GP, it was 52mm, grade 2 - in my lymph nodes. I am happy now - not all the time, who is,  but I smile and laugh and appreciate life. You will get there too, but it's early days! Nobody, just nobody, can predict what will happen with any individual cancer - you can look at averages and statistics but we are all individuals and will have our own outcome. I hope you had a nice evening with your family. Take care of yourself as you recover! R

Posts.Content: Hi NN17 I see you've already had some great advice and reassurance. I just wanted to add a couple of things. Firstly, you should be able to get your report if you ask for it. I wasn't given mine and was dealt with quite coldly when I rang the BCN number. They told me to ring the patient liaison department and they were extremely kind and helpful and printed off a whole load of reports and sent them to me.  It is shocking when our diagnosis changes and can be devastating but please don't panic - it is still treatable, it just needs more treatment. Another point is that you do have a choice - I am not remotely suggesting you refuse treatment but I think  it's important to remember that you have a say in all of this and it is OK to ask why they are recommending a certain treatment and how it will benefit you. Having said that - I asked them to throw everything they had at it, but that is me and if you are not comfortable about having a treatment, then you should feel that you can have another appointment to talk about it. I'd also like to reassure you that you might find chemo very manageable. I was told not to work because I teach and the infection risk was too high - but I could have. I met up with friends, did some projects round the house, helped my daughter move and kept up my running regime for most of it. No-one can predict how you will find it but lots of us fare well with it. You have had a shock at your results appointment and it will take a little time to get used to it - I can understand how heartbroken you must feel. Take things one day at a time and you will get through this  Have you checked out the breast cancer chemo club thread? Lots of practical advice as well as support from others having treatment. This is a path we'd rather not have to walk, but we will be with you every step! R

Posts.Content: Hi Shellian Sorry to read about your problems. I've just gone back to work after 2 years off - my financial situation did get quite bad and I had to deal with debt collection agencies etc. I still owe the water company quite a lot of money (well, they can't cut you off so they went straight to the bottom of the repayment list) I'm sure if Macmillan have advised you that you know everything I'm about to say but thought you might like to hear it from someone who went through it. Firstly you must contact everyone and tell them about your situation and agree an amount you can pay - some of mine were £1 a week - as long as you pay something, they will just check in with you now and again. You have to persevere on the phone, though to get put through to the right department - don't try not to cry - they'll redirect your call if you are that upset.  Most of the utility companies have a charity wing and can wipe your bill or reduce it if they think you are deserving enough - I got a hefty gas bill wiped completely. There is a charity which will help you organise all this and will write letters on your behalf (They are called Stepchange or something like that) That takes a bit of the worry out of it for you and they know exactly how to word things. There may be charities that can help you out financially - most industries have benevolent funds so you could look at whether there is one for whatever work you did, or what your partner does. The charity I just mentioned can have a look at that for you too.  This is not solely your problem - it is also your partner's problem. He may not be a very pro-active participant but he did go through cancer with you and it takes it's toll on everyone. He deserves help to get his family back on it's feet too and should also approach his finances with that mindset. I know it sounds cynical but I don't see the point of avoiding cynicism when we are talking about money. He is also deserving of sympathy and he must go out and get it - whether that be help with his accounts or more business to improve the situation sooner. Get a story in the local press, if that would benefit his business. Finally - it will eventually get better. It's frightening when you feel that you are drowning in the debt, but actually, once things are sorted and companies aren't harassing you - it becomes easier to deal with. It isn't pleasant and we shouldn't have to go through it but you do go THROUGH it - you come out the other side. I have a very different attitude to money now, because I can see that sometimes it's just numbers on bits of paper - people can just change those numbers or get rid of them without making a big difference to anybody else but you - so you must try to convince them to do that for you. I know how hard it is to tackle these things when you are at a low ebb and it is draining and feels like too big a hill to climb, but try to just put one foot in front of the other and you will get through. Do please persevere with getting help with it, as everyone has suggested - go back again and again if you need to until things are in place. Sending virtual hugs  R

Posts.Content: Hi - just popping on to say that it is often an insurance issue. Therapists must have public liability insurance and they must prove to the insurance provider they've had training in the treatments they offer. It is the insurance companies that refuse to provide the cover for clients who have had cancer unless the therapists have been specifically trained in it. There are a few companies that offer specific training. So yes - the treatment is exactly the same, but the therapist who is "trained" is the only one insured to do it. They aren't insured for anything different but let's say they are not insured to work on someone who has had cancer, they give a massage, the client has an allergic reaction - absolutely nothing to do with cancer treatment - there is no insurance. There is actually a lot of noise about this in the beauty industry right now because companies want to offer treatments but can't get the insurance - they are trying to encourage the government to lean on the insurance companies or have the training incorporated into the standard qualifications. Enjoy your spa! R

Posts.Content: Hi simba4me Hope you are feeling a bit better today! I just wanted to say that it's important to accept that you will recover at your own pace - it's frustrating but I have learnt the hard way that pushing yourself too much is a bad idea and there comes a point where you have to accept it and go with the flow. Your daughter has it right. I have always been resilient, determined, independent - but it is a year since my treatment ended and I am still recovering. I finished chemo in September 16, mx October 16 and rads finished December 16 - it was probably August this year before I could handle a day without a nap. I have had good support from my hospital and GP and have been told off for doing too much or the wrong thing or going too fast.  To be honest, there are people who have never had cancer who do less, but I wanted to be back to my usual level of strength and energy. I naively thought I'd be hurtling through my life at full speed again in a matter of months but it didn't turn out that way. There's every chance your recovery will be quicker - I had all sorts of nonsense going on like a seroma and infection, tendon problems in my arm etc. The thing is, we don't get to choose how quickly we recover and if you are someone who is usually in control that can be very hard. It's normal to be frustrated and I think it's fine if we feel a bit sorry for ourselves sometimes - we have had cancer! Looking after your husband must be hard, so really you are doing rather well! Be gentle on yourself and come here any time you need to let off steam Take care R

Posts.Content: I've followed this thread from the beginning and not commented because I have mixed feelings but thought I'd share them now so I get the notifications I don't like the campaign - it's the laughing and smiling that gets me - what a fun thing - all of that! It seems like it's taking the p**** somehow. But then, I didn't cold cap so I am willing to take some of the responsibility for the baldness I had, not that it should make any difference. I have had unhappy experiences with other aspects of Macmillan in the past, but this site has made me warm to them! I honestly don't know how well I would have coped without it - if Macmillan told me either the campaign could go or the online community - I'd accept the campaign in a heartbeat! I know that's oversimplifying things and a ridiculous comparison - also selfish - but it's how I reason it to myself and I look away from those ads. Right now, I'm not fundraising or volunteering etc so I think of silent acceptance as my contribution. The truth is - I am not the target audience - I know about Macmillan, I know about cancer - I'm likely to contribute anyway - it's designed to catch the attention of people who wouldn't otherwise - so it needs to be something they are going to want to do - like the Movember thing - it's catchy! That doesn't mean I agree with it or disagree with the complaints - like I said, my feelings are really mixed. What I would like though is for Macmillan to acknowledge how hard the reality is alongside  the jolly smiling shavers - to get people to talk about this disease freely so that in the future, people don't have to feel like this. An ad that shows both those things. When I was bald, I got taunted and ridiculed by a group of children in the park - that shouldn't happen!! Trust me, I told them exactly why I had no hair and they were embarassed and apologised, but I suspect they've never heard cancer spoken about other than people in a soap opera and probably didn't expect someone with cancer to be walking round the park laughing and chatting (with my daughter) That would be the pay off for me - fine, have the campaign - everyone shave their heads if they want to but in return, we get to say cancer like any other word, like any other disease as loud and as often as we like till it loses it's power. So people can be 'brave' enough to talk about it instead of copying it. I'd prefer that to a not very meaningful apology! R

Posts.Content: Hi L C D Sorry to hear you are having such a rough time of it! Clearing out can sap your energy at the best of times, let alone with all you are dealing with. We don't get to choose our families and they don't always treat us as we would like, but your family love you and I am sure have your best interests at heart. I found that one of the hardest things to deal with during cancer treatment was the loss of control. After years looking after others, it is hard to let people tell us what to do and since we have to let our doctors do that, it's the last thing we want our family to do! On the flip side - my daughter told me she felt powerless because she couldn't even contribute to making the decisions and she found it difficult when I made decisions she didn't understand. She promptly rearranged my spare room and one day I found her on the phone to my broadband provider making changes to my contract! We had words! Really, though she was overstepping the mark, she was trying to have some control over a situation that frightened her and I can understand that need. You are a mum and a daughter and I think your family are trying to protect you in their own way. They can't fix you but they are trying to 'fix' the sale of your house for you. It's a stressful and emotional time for all of you. Could you have an honest talk with them and tell them that you need some control over things? Maybe a plan of exactly how and when they can help? I hope you can sort this out with them so that you can do what you enjoy but also get some help from them. R
