Posts.Content: Hi Matohu just to echo what has been said already - we are all different and you may not get fatigue at all. If it hits, you will know. It is very different from tiredness and extra sleep doesn't really help. What works is gentle and increasing exercise, and figuring out what adjustments you can make to avoid it. Let's hope it doesn't hit you, but if it does, see if here is any help available for you. I referred myself to my hospital's cancer rehabilitation programme after treatment and have just been discharged. I used to run between 5 and 7k three times a week before cancer and did weights and circuit training another 3 days - I managed to keep running through a part of my treatment but the fatigue hit me after rads. I finished treatment at the end of 2016 and it has taken till about May this year to feel that my energy levels are back to normal - my fitness is much lower but I am working on it gradually. The fatigue still hits from time to time, particularly if I get a cold or something, but I have the strategy to cope with it now. The rehab team have told me I will find it comes back periodically but it should be less severe and I should recover from it faster. It's about finding the right balance between rest and activity. Fingers crossed this is all advice you never need! R

Posts.Content: Hi mrsox  I'm not sure if I have spoken to you about this before (it's hard to get me to be quiet about it) I had a single mastectomy, no reconstruction October 2016 but was approved for a double and can still request that if I wish - well, that's what they said at the time! Lots of surgeon's don't like to remove healthy tissue and it does seem to vary depending on your surgeon, your hospital and your reasons. My reasoning was for symmetry and not too much about getting cancer in the other breast although, of course, that is always in my mind. I had to have a few heated discussions with my surgeon and have a psychological assessment but they agreed to do a bilateral at the same time as removing the tumour. A WLE wasn't an option for me because of the size of the tumour and the fact that there were 2 smaller ones also. If your surgeon's are considering it (don't know which way the 60/40 is) then try to write down your reasoning and any responses to their arguments and see if you can open up that discussion again. As an example, my surgeon told me that no breast meant no follow up which he considered a risk, but then there is a higher risk of recurrence on my mastectomy side and I get no follow up there - just a mammogram on the other so I put that to him - along with other things. I think that, truly, they want to do what will be right for each of us, but they don't know us and only see us for 10 minutes here and there. They also have to follow the hospital ethos. My surgeon was very open about the fact that he has seen women make this decision and then regret it - probably his most powerful argument to me was that he would do whatever was needed to make me happy but that the only thing he couldn't do was give me my own breast back. I eventually decided not to have it done at the same time because I just had too much going on with chemo after effects. I am a wreck with surgery so am unlikely to ever ask for it but it's comforting to know it's there. Having got to know my surgeon better when I was seeing him 2/3 times a week with a seroma infection - I believe he had my best interests at heart.  If you are adamant that you want a bilateral then maybe raise it again and see if you can convince them. If they offer a psychological assessment - I would say go for it- I was a bit outraged about it at the time but the session really clarified things for me and showed me some things about my character that explained a lot!!!! hahaha. Hope the bone scan goes well R

Posts.Content: Hi all An interesting article - it's always difficult when looking at cancer incidence in other countries - I'm sure there's more than diet involved. Just to add my own view - I could have been the poster girl for healthy eating - don't like dairy - added natural yoghurt to my diet on doctors orders when I was diagnosed with osteopenia in my 30s but eat lots of kale for calcium, aim for 7 fruit/veg a day, don't eat processed foods, don't add sugar to foods, don't eat a lot of meat, drink water all day, exercise every day - got cancer anyway! Posts.Content: Hi suzy543 Just jumping in about the PN. Your oncologist sounds dismissive to say the least - definitely ask to see someone else within the hospital team if you can - you should be comfortable with your team. I had pretty bad PN when I was having treatment - it was the Docetaxel chemo I had. My oncology team told me they were going ahead with treatment regardless even though there was a risk it would be permanent (because of an issue with my liver at one point). They were pretty ruthless! I was on board with it, though and had told them to throw anything they could at me and that is the difference. This is your treatment and you should be involved and not dismissed - you have a right to be involved in the decisions. I was prescribed Pyridoxine but didn't find it that helpful and I found opinion differs very much on it's effectiveness - I suspect your oncologist is in the unimpressed camp. I sort of felt that I was being given it to show willing rather than because it would help significantly. However, some people take it with success and it is certainly not going to hurt. When my consultant surgeon saw the extent of my PN he was shocked - I had trouble holding a pen and signing my consent for surgery - so clearly the oncology team had not really recorded the extent of it. My surgeon paid more attention to it and asked questions and got me to do some tests to see what I could feel - the oncologists had never done that. I assume that the oncologists maybe see it differently and think it is an acceptable price for us to pay, but really, that should be our decision. BUT - on to more positive stuff. My treatment was in 2016 and it did resolve. I have very slight residual numbness in the very tips of my fingers and toes but nothing that hinders me in any way. For most people it does resolve in time, and there are quite a few people here who have had issues with it during treatment. You are definitely not alone. I think a little word with your BCN might be helpful - they might be able to suggest the best route for you to see a different oncologist. I hope your radiotherapy is going well - remember how well you have done to get this far. I think we all feel a little bereft as treatment comes to an end. In a way, we have dealt with the immediate threat, we know we are on the road to recovery and we can finally deal with our emotions properly.  We are all here for you whenever you feel alone - we completely understand what you're going through and we will cheer you on as you get to that finishing line! Posts.Content: Hi littleone31 just popping on to say that they are a very respected company - well known in the hair industry. You could approach them for some information as they are not chemo specialists - they may not recommend their system for chemo. Generally, most people advise a synthetic wig whilst having chemo and then other solutions after hair has re-grown a bit. Partly this is due to sensitivity and ease of use. I know that it is hugely daunting to face losing your hair and it's difficult to imagine being able to face the world, but a lot of people find that they don't mind as much as they thought or they don't like wigs or they don't like hats or whatever. It's difficult to predict how you feel until it happens. I thought I wouldn't care, but then found out I actually cared a lot. After a while I did get more used to it though. It would be a shame to invest a lot of money into a solution then find it wasn't right for you. Are you going to try the cold cap? Lots of people here have had success with it - you might find you don't lose too much hair. Whatever you choose - hope chemo is kind to you! R

Posts.Content: Hi Emmaj91 Welcome to the online community. Sorry to hear that you have this worry. If your GP has referred you for an urgent appointment, then you should be seen within 2 weeks and that length of time shouldn't change because of your age.  It is much, much less common for younger women to have breast cancer, and we have had some people on here who have felt they weren't taken as seriously, but I think that depends on your hospital.  The waiting is awful and there isn't anything that will take it away entirely, but I'd recommend trying to distract yourself as much as you can and avoid googling your symptoms - there's lots of nonsense out there. Of course, look at the reputable websites like Macmillan, Breast Cancer Care, Cancer Research UK if that helps - but stay away from the darker corners of the internet. Different places operate slightly differently - some have a sort of one-stop-shop set up, others will do an examination and book separate appointments for tests. Generally, you should be seen by some one from the breast surgery team. They will do a manual exam and ask you some questions. If they think it's necessary, they'll then send you for a mammogram and possibly ultrasound. This might be on the same day or they might make appointments for you.  The mammogram is basically an x-ray of your breasts - you will stand in front of the machine and they will help you place your breast onto a flat metal plate. They will then lower a second plate to flatten your breast and take the x-ray. Sometimes they repeat this at different angles. Depending on how the x-ray looks - they may send you for an ultrasound scan. You will lay on a couch and they will gently roll a small machine over your breasts to produce images on a screen. If you've ever seen someone have a pregnancy ultrasound - it's just like this. There may then be a core biopsy. You will be given a local anaesthetic and they will take a sample of anything they find. It is done with a needle and the worst bit is the noise - It sounds like a stapler. Biopsies usually take a few days to process so if they take one they will normally give you an appointment to go back for the results It's important to remember that the tests do different things so being sent for them doesn't always mean it's bad news. The mammogram can pinpoint something which looks unusual and the ultrasound gives a clearer picture of what that is. if there is something there and they can't tell what it is, then a biopsy tells them what it's made of. Please be assured, something like 90% of lumps referred to the breast clinic turn out to be something other than cancer. Of those that are cancer, about 90% are treated successfully. I have been referred to the breast clinic twice - once at about 30 which turned out to be cysts and once at 47 which turned out to be cancer. Both times I was seen within 2 weeks and had a manual exam, mammogram and ultrasound. It's a good idea to take someone with you to the appointment for a couple of reasons - you may find yourself emotional regardless of the result simply because of the stress of it all. Also there may be a lot of waiting around and that is always better with company.  We'll be thinking of you - let us know how you get on. R

Posts.Content: Hi susanneg Sorry this will probably be a lengthy reply! I am in a similar position though my surgery is in 2 weeks. I have asked for bilateral mastectomy for symmetry and ease - I like to run and exercise a lot and can't imagine doing that with a prosthesis - it is also quite difficult to find high impact post surgery sports bras! I won't deny there is also a fear of cancer in the other breast but it is not my main motivation - more like a bonus. However, the "medical people" seem to understand the fear aspect more than the cosmetic. My consultant doesn't really agree with my choice but he has said he will do whatever I want but wants to make sure I am making the right choice for me. I had a discussion with my BCN initially and another lengthy and heated discussion/argument with my consultant surgeon. I think he said it had to go to the MDT but I may be confused - no-one has mentioned it since and I am booked in now - perhaps they just agreed. I did have to have a psychological assessment which I believe is standard for this type of request. The psychologist I saw said it was very unusual and he wanted to discuss it with his consultant before he said yes - he then phoned me the next day with more questions but did agree I was capable of making the decision. I found the psychological assessment pretty intense but it ultimately clarified things for me - that I am concerned with the visual aspect of everything, that I am a perfectionist, that I am thinking about the impact on something which is a large part of my life. Ironically - now they have agreed and it is just around the corner, I am questioning my decision hahaha!  I saw my consultant a few days ago and had another discussion. His preference has always been to do one at a time but I don't want to be facing more surgeries - I have huge anxiety over the operation to the extent that we have had to discuss what they will do if I run away or refuse up to the point of anaesthetic! I am a definite flight risk. However, I am now considering whether I should have some time to see how I feel living with one breast (not that I will ever let my surgeon think he might have been right) So the point of telling you all this is partly to let you know you are not alone in your thinking (to me, they come as a pair!) but also to let you know you can go down this road and change your mind. My surgeon has asked me to make a decision by next week if I can so that they can make use of the theatre time if I don't need it - which I think is very reasonable. My choice is agreed now so if I have a single mastectomy now - I can ask for the other when I am ready. I can also change my mind and have a reconstruction later whether I choose single or double mastectomy. Have you seen a plastic surgeon yet? When I found out the implications of what was possible for me, it helped me make my decision - I was fairly reluctant but thought I might have reconstruction if the outcome would be "liveable". Once I was told the scenario for my size and shape of breast, I knew for sure I didn't want it but there is always the chance you might find the opposite. I completely understand how emotional and difficult this decision is and I admire all the women who make clear and firm decisions early on. However - you are you and this decision is to please only you so you will need to spend some time thinking about it, finding what you think is the best solution ( I think of it as the option I will hate the least - not very positive but works for me) and jumping in, knowing that you can change your mind!  I look forward to reading the other replies. Wishing you good luck and some ease making your decision! R
Posts.Title: Pros and cons of bilateral mastectomy/reduction

Posts.Content: Hi susanneg Thanks for the link to the article - interesting. I note symmetry was listed as a reason so clearly it is not as unusual as they would have us believe!  I completely understand this issue being the one that triggered an emotional respone for you. All along I have been told by my team that "surgery is the easy bit" and I suppose in one sense it is - relatively short and by now routine procedure - but it is the bit where they take our breast away and it all becomes very real. Like you, I had chemo first so was able to indulge in a bit of denial about the surgery and it then hit me when everyone started to want to make plans about halfway through chemo. It has been the hardest decision I have ever had to make! I wouldn't describe my surgeon as warm but he is nice - and honest when pressed! One of the things he did say to me was that he sees lots of women go through breast cancer and sometimes they regret their decisions. He said that the point of the psychological assessment was so that they could be sure that I wasn't going to turn around after surgery and say "why did you let me do that?" Actually, as cynical as I am, I believe that it would upset him on a professional level if that happened rather than being a butt-saving exercise. Now that we have agreed that my decision is right for me, he is openly concerned about making a nice flat chest with a neat scar. I sometimes forget that they are professionals who want to be proud of what they do. I was fully anticipating a much bigger fight when I asked for bilateral and was prepared to argue on very feminist/chauvinism grounds - along the lines of why is it acceptable that I have  countless surgeries to achieve symmetry so long as I have breasts at the end of it - but not acceptable that I achieve symmetry by doing without breasts? Luckily it didn't get to that, but in our enlightened times, I don't see how any trust can get away with refusing bilateral for symmetry. I think your surgeon needs to address this with you even if you decide to have reduction - or even reconstruction - it's important that you feel you have been given every option and made a decision that is right not just the one recommended!  A little note on my reasons for considering a unilateral first - I responded to another post here and made the point that what we all really want is to keep our own breast and that is the one thing they can never give us back. Up until that point - I hadn't said that to myself and it sowed a tiny seed of doubt which has made me consider being cautious - I am still certain I would rather be flat. That's what is so great about these forums - they give us the opportunity to clarify things! Interesting coincidence - I am also a college lecturer (I teach hairdressing and media makeup) and I think that idea of being "on show" does impact on our decisions - we need to be able to project a strong, authorative image so we need to be confident. Finally - here is a link to a web page about living without reconstruction in case you haven't come across it - the images helped me. http://breastfree.org/ Good luck with your next appointment - let us know how you get on! R

Posts.Content: Hi Lelotron I'm sorry to hear about your Dad - it must be very hard for you to deal with this diagnosis while you are still grieving. You do have some say in your treatment but doctors are very reluctant to remove what they see as healthy tissue. Last year, I went down the route of requesting a double mastectomy (which I didn't have in the end) and my surgeon was very reluctant to agree it because he said he had known women request it and then regret it later. He also argued that the chance of developing cancer in the "healthy" breast was only slightly higher than for someone who had never had breast cancer. Having said that, he was absolutely adamant that I needed a mastectomy instead of a WLE because I had more than one tumour and he thought it was safer - not all surgeons insist on that so he was definitely a "belt and braces" person but still thought a bilateral was unnecessary. My reasons were slightly different though because I was thinking more about the symmetry as I didn't want a reconstruction. To play devil's advocate - when you have a mastectomy, you have no follow up so would be responsible for checking for any recurrence yourself. I had a left mastectomy last year with no reconstruction and although I get a yearly mammogram on my right breast, there is nothing on the left. It is so difficult for us to make these decisions when we are diagnosed - our minds are all over the place and we need to see so many different people and have very little time to research. Have you thought about your reconstruction options? That might factor into the decision that you make - for example it's usual to have implants if you are having a bilateral mastectomy as not everyone would have enough tissue for a flap reconstruction. Also - you could always try to get an agreement for it in the future. I argued for my bilateral but was conflicted because I was dealing with some after effects of chemo so my surgeon suggested I get approval (I had to have a psychological assessment) but keep it as an option for the future and that's what I did in the end. I have the option to request it but as time goes on I feel less and less inclined to go through more surgery It's completely understandable that you are worried but hopefully your other aches and pains will turn out to be anxiety related - worry and stress can cause havoc with our bodies. You have a little bit of time to think about your options and it might be worth making an appointment to have another discussion - maybe with your BCN? It's a tough decision and I hope you can find the right solution for you! R

Posts.Content: Hi I don't know about the dye you mention specifically. If you mix it with anything - a seperate lotion or even water - then it can potentially have the same reaction as any other hair dye. That's possible allergy or scalp sensitivity. Even henna which is ground up leaves can cause an allergy. The issue with chemo is mainly your scalp rather than your hair - though that can be fragile too. Also, colouring white hair is not as easy as picking a colour and applying it as they are designed to be applied to hair that has pigment so you could end up with something orangey, yellow etc. If you have a hairdresser you trust, they should be able to patch test you as a precaution and use a technique that keeps the dye away from the scalp - like highlights. I would also give a vote for grey or white hair - very in just now - I bet you look fabulous! R

Posts.Content: Hi Violet blue Welcome to the forums and sorry you find yourself in this position. I was diagnosed last February and had my op in October (chemo first) so had plenty of thinking time. I chose a mastectomy without reconstruction. You are right - it's a big deal.  One important thing to remember is that this doesn't have to be your final decision. You can change your mind and have a reconstruction later or have one removed. I actually asked for a bilateral mastectomy for symmetry - my breasts were reasonably large. I ended up having only one removed with the option of having the other removed when I am ready. I am not keen on the lopsided me, but whether I will ever pluck up the courage for another operation, I don't know. However, I have always been indifferent to my breasts - I'm just not a woman who feels attachment to them anymore than to other body parts but I know other women do so my choice would not be right for them. There are a couple of things that helped me with my decision - one was looking at (non-gory) images and the other was something I read in a breast cancer book written by a breast surgeon.She said she always tells her patients that they are all false breasts - you are deciding whether you want to wear them under or over your skin. Here's a website where you can see good images of flat mastectomies http://breastfree.org/ Feel free to ask any other questions you have. R

Posts.Content: Hi anni69 Thought I'd reply as I am very slowly learning a very difficult lesson! I've run for years for my sanity (also teach) not a lot, between 3 and 5 miles 3 times a week. I did run through half my chemo - my oncologist was a little shocked but said it was fine if I could manage it. Once I had a Hickman line in, I stopped because I was worried about getting all sweaty under the dressing and getting an infection. I also got more tired as the T treatments went on. However, my treatment finished last year and I got myself back to exercise very slowly and in April had worked myself up to running for 4 minutes! I was so proud! I have just joined an exercise rehabilitation programme at my hospital and they have told me to stop the running. I still have fatigue and was told exercise  would help and I do love running! So thought I was doing well but they have told me it's too much and I have to admit that since I stopped, the fatigue is much better. So I am realising that there isn't one solution for everyone and it isn't always a good thing to push ourselves. It is very difficult and very frustrating to be exercising at the pace they want me to but I have to accept it is what's right for my body. I didn't need exercise - I needed rest! So see how you feel, but try to listen to your body and find what is the right thing for you - maybe running, maybe not. Good luck R

Posts.Content: Hi 3301apk Firstly, I will out myself as a hairdresser before I say the best thing is to involve your hairdresser! The not colouring thing is largely to do with scalp sensitivity after chemo which can lead to a reaction - this can happen with any colours you mix, even some of the ones you mix with water - the reaction can come from the ingredients in the dyes themselves and not the thing you mix them with. Lots of people do colour their hair straight away without a problem but if you do develop a reaction, it can be something you will then have for ever so I think it's a big risk to take. Colouring white hair is not always simple either and some post chemo hair can be resistant and harder to colour. Doing it yourself can lead to some unexpected results. By far the safest is the colour shampoos you suggest - a lot of salons sell a range of them and would be able to give you advice - you'll get more colour choice than in a chemist and some expert help. Of course they may try to convince you to book an appointment, but on the whole, we are a pretty compassionate and helpful bunch of people and I'm sure you'll find them only too willing to recommend something that will work for you. I am a year since my last chemo and only just about to colour my hair - and I've coloured it since I was 14! One of the champions once posted Trevor Sorbie's brilliant website for post chemo hair - I can't remember who, sorry but you could google it for info! R

Posts.Content: Hi cehfin I'm not in your position, chemo wasn't optional for me (other than refusing it) but I would have said yes because that's what I'm like - I wanted to throw everything at it. It depends on what is concerning you - if it's fear - lots of us here have been through chemo with few side effects. If you are otherwise fit and well, there's every chance you'll cope well.  I didn't work while on chemo because I teach and the infection risk is ever present in a college. I got on with life though - even managed to run 3 times a week through the first 4 treatments. Pennymoon is quite right - things have changed! It's not a walk in the park but it's very manageable! I have far worse side effects from surgery and radiotherapy than from chemo. I think the chemo side effects are so visible that it scares people. They can handle most side effects with the right drugs and as long as you follow the hygiene rules and take your temperature regularly you can minimise the risks. It's a tough call - if you are hormone positive then you have hormone therapy to fall back on, but chemo is a very effective whole body treatment - I'm glad I've had it. You can always ask for another oncology appointment if you need it. Good luck making this difficult decision R

Posts.Content: Hi I'm posting this because I see the 'is this normal?' threads quite often and I know it can seem disappointing when you feel that you're not doing as well as you should, because that has been me! I've also realised that there are people who read and don't post so this is just some reassurance in case there is anyone who feels like I've been feeling. Well, it's been 7 weeks since my mastectomy and node clearance and they have been a long 7 weeks!  Like loads of us, before cancer I lived my life at 100mph - work, family, exercise, hobbies, socialising and that has all screeched to a halt and it has been the hardest thing for me to deal with, so when I didn't bounce back after the operation, it really got me down! I've not been able to sleep; I've not been able to get up in the mornings; I've needed a nap after doing anything; I've not been able to drive; I've had pain in the bits that are there and the bits that have gone; I do my exercises but the progress is so slow and I still don't have full movement; I've not been able to shop and cook properly; There have been days when I struggled to motivate myself to do anything. It has just been pants! -  and it has felt like forever! When I run up a hill, I look at the ground so that it's not about the whole hill, just the next step - and that's how I've been dealing with my cancer. Today, I finally had the energy to look up and realise that I have come a long way already and that I am closer to the top and I am going to get there.   I'm not back to normal - I'm not even as fit and well as I was during chemo, and I start radiotherapy next week and probably have to deal with another lot of issues and side effects, but I am just so glad that today I feel myself again - I managed a little drive and a lap of the park and didn't need a nap! I feel motivated now. So I just wanted to say to anyone who is post op and struggling or feels despondent, that it does get better - a lot of people are over it in a few weeks, but some of us need longer! No matter how long it takes we will all get there eventually! R

Posts.Title: Finished at last!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi tiger-777 It's a hard decision isn't it. I thought I'd reply as trying to make that decision was what brought me to this site about a year ago. I am a 34F and was initially told lumpectomy but they found a second tumour so advised a mastectomy. I had chemo first so had lots of time to think about it - and I did - round and round in circles. Funnily enough, after all that thinking and research, I've ended up with exactly what I would have agreed to on my very first appointment! I had a unilateral mastectomy. I really didn't like the plastic surgeon I met and having a reduction on the other breast was never suggested to me, but lots of tweaking and lifting was spoken about and it put me off reconstruction. I then asked for a bilateral mastectomy - my thinking was that I'd then be even and could choose whether or not to wear prosthesis and could choose the size (tidy B or C cup). I had to have a psychological assessment which is standard at my hospital and my surgeon agreed to it. Then I decided not to have it done at the same time. That was what my surgeon wanted and I was so fed up with some of the lingering effects from chemo I just couldnt face the thought of 2 arms that didn't want to move. It's in reserve for another time. Anyway - the point of telling you all that is - now it is about 8 months since my surgery and a lot of the problems I imagined haven't occured. One major thing is that chemo seems to have made my remaining breast much softer and lighter and less dense (I had very lumpy dense breasts with multiple cysts when I was diagnosed) so I have never felt the difference in weight and I am coping with a non-wired bra which I didn't think I would. I was so worried about the weight of a prosthesis and how it would feel when I went running - but I haven't even been for the fitting yet - I just wear a softie or a knitted knocker and I don't notice. I was worried about how it would feel if I didn't wear a prosthesis in bed because I sleep on my front - I don't notice. I am the kind of person who gets bogged down in the detail but I was probably overthinking it all - you probably know deep down what you want and that's what you should ask to have. Try to have a very honest discussion with all your team - it was actually my BCN who was helpful and supportive on this although she was fairly useless at everything else. Also, see what the situation is about future treatment - when I asked my plastic surgeon about corrections if I changed my mind he gave a massive sigh so I didn't feel I'd be able to backtrack if I hated it. When I asked my breast surgeon, though, he told me he wanted me to be happy so I could have whatever I wanted within reason - it made me more comfortable about making the decision. Whatever you choose doesn't have to be permanent - and there is every possibility that you will find that you adapt to whatever you have - our brains can do a great job of  compensating so we don't notice things - I knocked my softie the other day then grabbed it to minimise the pain - took a few seconds to register why it wasn't hurting!  There are lots of fantastc women here who  can advocate for reductions and reconstructions etc and they'll be along to help - I just wanted to reassure you that a bigger breast might not be as much of a problem as you think. Good luck with the decision - I know how tough it can be! R

Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Hi Beth567 10 days is still early. You have had to deal with the traumatic experience of surgery and recovery, as well as the emotional issue of losing parts of your body, and adapting to the new visual image of yourself. It takes time. I think I may have recommended the pictures to you - and probably said that I am quite fond of my scar now. I am but it took time - months rather than years, but certainly not days. At this stage, you are not yet properly healed and your skin hasn't settled - this isn't how it will look in a couple of months.  I think you said you will be having reconstruction in the future? I am no psychologist, but I imagine that is harder to deal with in a way. For me it was a choice to not have reconstruction so there was more incentive for my mind to find positives, but if you do want a reconstruction, then that is what your mind will be accepting as a final result, so it is harder to accept what you see now - if it isn't your end goal. Have you had a post surgery check up? You could ask your team about the fluid - usually your body will absorb it, but you might want to get it checked to reassure yourself. I didn't wear a proper bra for about 3 weeks - I wore a soft, front fastening post-surgery bra with a softie only if I was out the house. To be honest, I waited nearly a year to get my silicone prosthesis. Does it get better? Yes, Yes, Yes! Be kind to yourself - allow yourself to grieve for what you have lost. How would you treat a friend in this situation? Be at least as kind to yourself. Once you are fully healed, massaging helps - I'd give your team a call and see what they recommend. The physio at my breast clinic taught us to massage by drawing the alphabet with our palms - she said it was the right amount of time and made sure you were massaging in all directions. Hope you are feeling a bit better this evening - sending some hugs your way R

Posts.Title: Waiting on biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hi julie2014 Sounds like you've had quite a shock. Firstly, you should be under a consultant - you might not always meet him or her but presumably that person exists somewhere and you should be able to request to see them. grannymush37 has given you some good advice but I wanted to let you know that a similar thing happened to me. Did the increase in tumour size and the other breast get picked up by a scan? Mine was my MRI - that gave a slightly increased tumour size, showed another tumour they hadn't seen on ultrasound (a third showed up in the pathology after my mastectomy) and a suspected tumour in my other breast which they couldn't find after a second lot of ultrasounds and biopsies - it niggles at the back of my mind still and I am 6 months post treatment. I found all this out the day before my first chemo - got an emergency appointment for ultrasounds and biopsies the morning of my first chemo treatment and promptly turned up at the chemo unit in tears, refusing to have chemo and completely bewildered as to why the plan hadn't changed.  Different scans show different things so this can sometimes happen, but of course no matter how this came about, you need to have confidence in your team and it sounds like this has shaken yours. You can always ask to see your consultant - or one of his team and should be allowed as many appointments as you need - I was quite a pest at times but I wanted to be comfortable and confident about my treatment. If you haven't already contacted your BCN - that sounds like a good start - someone to explain it all, how it happened etc. Mine was also a kind of gatekeeper to my consultant - I had to see her first and if she couldn't answer my questions (which was most of the time) she would make an appointment for me to see the consultant again. I hope your appointments go well today - let us know R

Posts.Title: Wearing a strapless bra after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Scaredgirl34 Yes this all sounds normal. Breast cancer treatment is very effective these days and the medical professionals know exactly what they're doing. Unfortunately, sometimes I think they forget we worry and can "drip feed" information to us. I'm sure that's helpful to some people. It's very much like a conveyor belt of treatment. My hospital do a bone scan, CT scan and MRI as standard and I had them before we knew my nodes were affected, but not all hospitals do. I think a chat with your BCN is a good idea.  The diagnosis stage is worrying and frightening - once treatment starts you will feel better.  Positive nodes show that the cancer was trying to spread but as others have said - the lymph nodes are there to catch them and chemo is a full-body treatment that is very effective in killing off individual cancer cells. It would be pointless to tell you not to worry, but try to distract yourself and contact your unit on Monday. I felt I had to be very pro-active as a patient. Help was definitely there but I had to ask for it - it wasn't often suggested to me - so give your nurse a call and see if she can chat with you - if not there might be other options she can suggest. We are all here for you too - this site was my main source of support and information there are a lot of lovely understanding and helpful people to get you through this. R

Posts.Content: Hi LittleWren I'm afraid I can't give you any advice but I am in the same situation - I'm 48 and last chemo is next week. If you get on well with your breast care nurse maybe have a chat with them - mine was sympathetic to my feelings and supportive - my surgeon is more opinionated but then he is looking at it from a surgical point of view - that's his job. You will most likely make the right decision for you but if not you can change it later. Good luck - hope you feel better after the meeting! R

Posts.Title: Noisy mastectomy wound

Posts.Content: Hi Londonfornow Sadly the answer is no. Waxing will stimulate the flow of lymph fluid to the area so will increase the risk of lymphoedema. I asked my BCN and she had no idea (she doesn't seem to know much) so I asked a friend who is a beauty therapist and has had breast cancer and she said absolutely not! I think most therapists will go ahead and wax anyway because it isn't something they will necessarily know about. No waxing - no shaving - when my treatment is over I am going to look into laser or light removal but fear that will be a no too! Take care R

Posts.Content: Hi Edwina I was going through this just before my BC diagnosis (my gynae appointment was scheduled about 2 weeks after I got my initial biopsy results) I was on Tranexamic acid which was not helping at all. It was actually my GP who said to me "this is enough - it's affecting your quality of life and you need to do something about it" Mine was due to fibroids (I knew this already) and the gynae suggested hysterectomy if it continued after BC treatment - or to ask for Zoladex from the onc team (I was hormone positive). Thankfully, treatment stopped my periods. I'm assuming you are not on any hormone treatment? If you are then going through your breast clinic might be an alternative route - Tamoxifen can cause issues with the womb and they could refer you to gynaecology. Otherwise, go to your GP and ask/demand to be referred. I suspect that as your bleeds aren't too  frequent, they are trying less invasive options and hoping that menopause will kick in naturally, but coping with that amount of bleeding is difficult. Put your foot down and get this sorted in a way that suits you - at the very least you need a chat with a specialist. R

Posts.Content: Hi GK1 I had a bit of a discussion with my oncologist about the 2 different types of drugs. He said that it is possible to take Tamoxifen pre and post menopause and that the reason they now switch people on to AI's post menopause is that research shows better survival rates for women who switch. I was wary of the AI's because of the side effects and he has put me on Tamoxifen and to review my decision after a year (I have treatment induced menopause) He told me I can stay on Tamoxifen the whole 10 years if that's what I want but it isn't his advice. I know people who take it with no side effects - I get hot flushes but probably would in natural menopause anyway. Lots of people find the brand makes a difference so you could give it a try and see how it goes and then try a different brand if you have problems. The decision to take it or not is entirely yours but it has been used for a long time and lots of women take it without any problem. R
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen for post menopausal women

Posts.Content: Hi Purplejan It's an absolutely huge decision to make - and only you will ultimately know what is right for you. I had grade 2 IDC, node involvement, 5cm main tumour - multi focal so WLE was not an option and am coming up to 4 weeks post mastectomy. I had chemo first as the second tumour was found too late to change course - this gave me 6 months of thinking and researching time. What I ultimately decided was that I wanted a bilateral mastectomy without reconstruction - I have not had that - though I can opt for it in time. I had to have many meetings, discussions and a psychological assessment to be approved for it so thought I'd share what was said to me. My decision was mainly about symmetry and not wanting to wear a prosthetic 24/7 (I ruled out reconstruction as an option for me early on) Those ideas seem difficult for the medical team to understand and it was assumed I was motivated by fear - that was an element of it - true enough! My consultant kept pointing out that the greater risk was recurrence in the same breast or secondaries. Mastectomy reduces the risk of recurrence and contralateral disease - it doesn't remove it as there will always be some cells left behind. If you opt for a flap reconstruction, any cancer that develops in remaining breast cells will grow into that tissue - so you can still end up with a breast with a tumour in it. He also wanted me to understand that with no breast tissue, there is no screening. It's standard practice at my hospital to request psychological assessment in this situation - I found it more intense than I expected but it was actually helpful in clarifying my thoughts. The psychologist understood my reasoning and approved my decision. I would say that the fact it was based on symmetry and practicality reassured him - but that is partly because it fits with my personality. What they are worried about is that you will make a decision based on an exaggerated fear that you will later regret (and screening out underlying mental health issues) My surgeon gave me quite a heartfelt speech about how many women he has seen change their minds and how he didn't want me to turn around and say "why did you let me do that?" I am not trying to influence you at all - just sharing the information given to me. Ultimately I chose a single mastectomy because of lingering side effects from treatment - it just all felt like too much to handle!  However, my surgeon constantly reminds me that I can have further surgery on one or both breasts in time should I change my mind (within reason) Have you had a good, long discussion with any of your team? I started with my BCN. Have you discussed your reconstruction options in depth - with one and two breasts?  Bear in mind that you are now contemplating a non-essential surgery so there will be some waiting time - I was told about 6 months from the time I request it to getting an appointment - so you can go down this road and change your mind - 2 months post surgery isn't really that long - and presumably not much longer than that since diagnosis? You are probably still very emotional and that may be why you are finding it hard to make a decision. Hopefully you will find your team supportive in investigating your options - there is no cancer in your remaining breast so you can afford to take your time to make this decision and I think you'll know when your decision is right. Wishing you all the best with it R

Posts.Content: Hi Davewj and welcome to the online community. The other discussion that Leolady56 has given you a link to might be worth a read as it was very recent and will potentially connect you with some of our other men, but please don't assume that you will necessarily get the same side effects as someone else. We have fewer men here than women so most of the anecdotal evidence we can share with you is from a woman's perspective but I haven't read anything about Tamoxifen that suggests there is a gender difference when it comes to side effects. Depression is a side effect, but not a common one - it affects about 10% of people. Of course, depression and cancer can go hand in hand with or without Tamoxifen. A lot of people find that they tolerate one brand more than another, so if you do start to experience side effects that you find difficult to manage then speak to your GP about switching brands - they tend to automatically prescribe the cheaper ones - well why wouldn't they - but I have found both my GP and the pharmacy to be very understanding about me asking for a specific brand. I would suggest speaking to your GP about the skin itching and see if they can give you something to relieve it. There is a very comprehensive page of side effects info on the Cancer Research UK website - here's a link Hope you are recovering well R

Posts.Title: Results end chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Raggarty Sorry to hear you are struggling - I just wanted to say that you're not alone. I haven't found recovery easy and that frustrates me because I pride myself on being tough as old boots (well, I did) I just scraped through my radiotherapy planning session and was crying with pain all through the first session. Once treatment finished, I broke my arm, then got a seroma, then an infection in the seroma, now a splint on my hand because of an inflamed tendon when I tried to go back to work. It seemed never-ending. Haven't made it back to work properly yet 18 months after diagnosis. It is tough! We think we will bounce back and everyone thinks we will be fine as soon as treatment is finished but it isn't the case for everyone. some of us take longer to heal Can you take some time off work? You are still having treatment so your GP should sign you off. I know you may not want to - how about asking for reduced hours? It's an awful lot to cope with while you are working and you do need to be kind to yourself. if you're not sure about asking for reduced work - the helpline are great at that sort of thing and can tell you what you're entitled to. I know it seems daft, but when he was treating my infection, my consultant eventually had a chat with me about how much I was doing, what I was eating etc and made me realise how much my body had been through and that I needed to rest and eat the right food to recover properly - the very old-fashioned notion of convalescence. You will get there!  R

Hope everything starts to improve for you soon! R

Posts.Content: Hi Beenie I'm going to go against the grain here and say I'm not impressed with the M+S mastectomy bra range (which is what you might need for a while) I find the cups a very odd shape and actually, they have very limited choice in larger sizes. I know they were developed with the help of women who had undergone breast surgery but they don't work for me. I didn't have recon by the way so that may make a difference, but I know other women who feel the same. Considering they are so well known for underwear - they don't even offer matching sets. Also - you have to request the VAT off at the till which annoys me - lol, not a fan can you tell? I will big up their post surgery sports bra though - the best I've found! I am a 34E/F and I struggle to find bras that fit - even the specialist suppliers offer very little in this size - it's so disappointing. I suspect you will need a partial breast form for your reconstruction side - I don't know if you will be fitted for one - it's worth speaking to your BCN, you can get your own from specialist suppliers, or you maybe able to use the cheaper "chicken fillet" type. So - a few suggestions: I had a bra fitting at John Lewis - they have an appallingly small post-surgery range - we should all email them! Anyway, my fitting was before my mastectomy but during treatment and they were amazing - the woman spent a couple of hours with me finding the right bra and was not at all phased by my appearance (at the time I had no hair, eyelashes etc, one blue breast and tubes coming out of my chest - not the most confidence-building look) I don't buy bras from them now because the range is so small but someone did tell me they will sew a pocket into a non surgery bra so it may be an option for you. Debenhams stock a variety of post-surgery ranges and some stores do post-surgery fittings (I think they are trained by Amoena) they also don't put VAT on their post-surgery bras so you don't have the awkwardness of asking for it to be taken off. They do their own range, too which is very reasonably priced. The lady who did my prosthesis fitting recommended Bravissimo to me - purely for the size issue. I haven't been yet (it's so expensive buying a whole new load of bras after surgery) but it has been recommended quite often by other people on here and I think they might also sew a pocket into a normal bra for you A few people on here recommended just sewing a pocket into my old bras but I don't have the sewing skills (yet- I'm working on it) but that might be an option, if you are handy with a sewing machine. You might find you are comfortable with a standard bra - I don't know. I am guessing it all depends on the size, shape and position of the partial form.  Hope you are soon able to sleep a little better! R
Posts.Title: Feeling all sorts of mixed emotions!!

Posts.Content: Hi florence 2017 I was diagnosed around the same time as you and I am only just getting back to normal. Everyone is different but I certainly wasn't expecting to still feel as slow and lethargic as I have been 6 months after my treatment finished (I had chemo, surgery, rads, now on Tamoxifen) I've had some other issues too including a nasty infection and my GP thinks it's understandable to feel like that and I am taking part in a post cancer exercise programme at my hospital and the physios there do laugh gently at me, reel off everything my body has been through this last year and ask if I really expect to be bouncing around full of energy. For me, that's part of the problem - my life was fast-paced with long hours, little sleep - just always on, but I always had the energy to keep going - so this feels unbearably slow by comparison. I am a bit more forgetful and have some word-finding problems but it's slowly improving. I wanted to give you some encouragement because last Saturday I woke up to a different world - it was weird, I just knew things had changed as soon as I got up - I was me again. Nobody else would be able to see a difference, but I feel it. I told the physios at the exercise session and they immediately claimed credit for it!! Actually, I do think it's a combination of time, finding the right pace to do things and having new challenges with the exercise. It's an hour a week at the hospital gym but it's all new to me and I think that might be what has helped because I am engaging my brain and my body in learning something at the same time - does that make any sense? I feel like the fog has finally lifted. I've been warned that I can slip back and not to get too excited or overdo it but it's a relief just to know it's not permanent! So - hang in there. Now, having said all of that - of course it could be a deficiency as everyone says so best to check that out first!  Fingers crossed for you that it soon improves! R

Posts.Content: Hi kathleen37 I agree with the others that the whole diet/cancer thing is a minefield. There are so many sites out there with conflicting information and, of course most diets come with a "check with your GP if you have health problems" clause. We do have an Ask a Dietician page here - you could pose this question to her - she'll aim to get back to you in 2 working days. I put on about 2 stone over chemo in 2016 and finding it hard to lose it completely and consistently but I'll get there I'm sure. At my hospital's moving on event we were advised to follow the World Cancer Research Fund diet which is a basic healthy diet - lots of fruit and veg, whole grains and meat no more than twice a week. This was for reducing cancer risk, though - not weight loss and was a general information session for all types of cancer - not necessarily hormone positive ones so I think there is a difference. You have a very specific question.  I hope you find an answer and have success with whichever diet you choose! R

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic Don't apologise - we all worry! I have lymph node involvement. Because I had chemo first, I know for sure that 3 were involved, but it's possible it was more. The job of the lymph nodes is to stop infection spreading so ideally, they would catch the cancer cells and stop them escaping. We know that doesn't always happen but sometimes it does.  The idea of chemo is to kill off any stray cancer cells that have escaped.  Do you know if your tumour was oestrogen positive?  Hormone treatment is also designed to stop cells growing in the body Unfortunately there are no guarantees - but things can turn out well against the odds as well as turn out badly. I was diagnosed 9 months ago - some days I think I'm going to die tomorrow - some days I think I'll be bungee jumping for my 85th birthday! It has taken me time to get to that point, though. At first I used to cry every day - now it's every week. I am confident that eventually I won't be crying at all. It's still early days for you so of course you will worry, but try to remember that you can't predict what will happen - you can choose to dwell on it or not. You are still experiencing after effects from surgery and as time goes on you will feel better. I mentioned this book a few days ago, but I really can't recommend it enough - I read about it on here and it's been so useful to me to calm me. Dr Susan Love's breast book she explains cancer, treatment, lifestyle changes etc. I think you'll feel more settled once you get your surgery results and get started on the rest of your treatment plan. You will worry less in time and we are all here for you! R

Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Hi Islanikita  I'm back to offer you some words of encouragement. I am 48 - I was diagnosed in February but had 8 rounds of chemo so am only a few weeks ahead of you - actually my radiotherapy is due to start 5th December so you are catching up with me fast!! I feel exactly like you and thought the surgery was the worst to contemplate - I have really struggled with it - and I am finding it hard to recover from - so tired and stiff and in pain nearly 6 weeks later. I have to ask myself if it is partly psychological. I did not want to look like this, I did not want to feel like this - one thing that freaks me out is if I drink a cold drink and I can feel it all over that side of my chest!  Anyway - I have a really big problem with surgery so have decided against reconstruction (so far) my solution was to have a bilateral mastectomy so that I could be even. It was a bit of a struggle to get it approved but I didn't have it in the end - it is an option for the future. For weeks I wouldn't look at both breasts at the same time - went to great lengths including taping fabric over the flat one to wash! Anyway - now I am starting to feel a bit better about it - I am never going to love it but I think I can accept it. It is a constant reminder, you're right and that word deformed - yes that is how I feel too and wish the other one was smaller. But - we don't have cancer anymore. We made a sacrifice in order to survive. When I wanted a bilateral, I had to have a psychological assessment and it was the first time I thought anyone understood how I felt. I think that in a few weeks you will begin to feel better, but do consider some therapy or counselling if you don't - this is a hard road we're on!  When you start to sort out your reconstruction, as others have said - you can have surgery to both breasts so can reduce if that's what you want.  More practically - when I had a proper meltdown over buying bras - people recommended amoena. I had seen their bras but not been on their website - if you haven't been on it - have a look. They have loads of bras - some really pretty ones, practical ones - they even have matching sets!  I got 4 softies - 2 of the biggest and 2 small so I could sort out the sizing (I didn't have drains so have had fluid to deal with and a constantly changing size) Don't worry about the size of them - they seem to only come in 3 sizes. I do find that they look different depending on the style of bra I wear - I have one T shirt bra with a firm cup and that seems to disguise any difference in size or shape. I always used to wear an underwire so find the weight of my remaining breast is a problem in some bras. I initially told my BCN that I didn't want a silicone prosthesis - they feel heavy! But we had a discussion and I will give it a try. I was given a link for a knitted knocker by Kacang - (she's in Australia so is here at night but will hopefully respond - she has a very positive take on mastectomy) I am going to knit one - I told my BCN and she couldn't stop laughing - said she thought they could do a bit better than that - guess what she's getting for Christmas!! Of course your confidence has taken a bashing - you have been through so much! How is everything else? Hair, brows, nails? I don't recognise myself right now but I look on here and see people get over this and get on with their lives so we will too! It's a pep talk several times a day for me at the moment but we will get there. In truth, people are looking at us much less than we think - nobody is analysing your breasts, I'm sure. One thing I make a point of doing is telling people when I am admiring something about them - someone once wisely told me that we always think the worst when people look at us but they might actually be thinking you are wearing exactly the jumper they've been looking for. It's true! So put your softie in, look them in the eye and get your confidence back a little at a time. Bit of a long post - sorry. Here's some links - (if they work) http://www.amoena.com/uk-en/ you can request a knitted knocker here http://www.knittedknockersuk.com/ this is my previous post where everyone gave me bra advice community.macmillan.org.uk/.../924541 Hope you are feeling happier soon! R
Posts.Title: Made to feel like a freak because I am larger breasted

Posts.Content: Hi Solow Welcome - as the others have said, we are all here for you! We are a big, friendly group - all at different stages of treatment. Some of us are finished treatment and stick around to give back the help and support we got. Hopefully that gives you reassurance that this is treatable and you will get through it. It is very early days for you and the worry is natural - I am sure there are all sorts of fears keeping you awake. For now, try to distract yourself - worry is exhausting. Talk as much as you need to - here if you are not comfortable talking to your nearest and dearest - it really does help. Having a treatment plan helps and then, starting treatment you will find that you just kind of put one foot in front of the other, one day-one step at a time until it is done. Of course you will worry about your husband and your children - it can be tough on our loved ones too, but you will look after each other and you can all get through this together. The helpline (0808 808 00 00 available Monday - Friday 9am - 8pm)  is a good place to talk too and your husband and children can also use it if they need to. There is an organisation called riprap that provides support specifically for teenagers with parents who have cancer - that might be useful to your children.       I finished treatment nearly a year ago and I found the forum by chance half way through chemo - it was the first time I had ever joined in anything like this and I am so glad I did - it has been invaluable to me. You will soon get the hang of it - there are some help topics here - but really, just shout if you are having any problems. Let us know how the oncology appointment goes on the 13th. R
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Cocopops1 Welcome to the site - hopefully you will find support and reassurance here! Please don't blame yourself - I suspect you are not stupid - you did what many women do! When I felt a lump it took me 2 months to go to my doctor for one reason and another - I don't think it was any bigger the day I had my tests than the day I first felt it - and with dense tissue and multiple benign cysts, I wouldn't have felt it when it was smaller. It's a scary time for you and difficult not to panic - it is standard to be seen within 2 weeks when you have any lump in your breast - sometimes you get an appointment sooner than that - my first experience of the breast clinic was 12 years ago - it turned out to be a cyst but my appointment that time came through in a few days! You will probably have a mammogram and ultrasound and core biopsy as you say. My hospital are pretty open and I 'knew' from the mammogram they thought it was cancer - the doctor doing the ultrasound checked if I had anyone with me before he said too much - I went to work afterwards in complete denial. I'm only telling you this because you might want to have someone supportive with you - maybe don't be as unprepared as me!!! I was also introduced to my breast care nurse that first day - yep still managed to stay in denial. I got my results 3 days later because that was when the results clinic is - same day each week.  Your hospital might do things differently, but rest assured, they do this all the time - they understand we are afraid, they will help to make the process easy no matter what it turns out to be. Breast cancer research is well funded and treatments improve all the time - as Crytaljuju says - success rates are high. I am slightly needle phobic - WAS slightly needle phobic - everyone is very tolerant of my little screams! I think they're used to it - I chat away like a mad thing to try to distract myself! You will cope! Good luck - keep posting here when your mind is in overdrive! R
Posts.Title: Scary times ahead

Posts.Content: Hi  JMC04  Lovely to hear from you - glad all is well! I always remember you saying you felt like you had us all in your pocket!! It's such a good way of putting it. Take care R
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Hi Daisy31 Wow - what a shock for you! That's a difficult decision - even more so when it's out of the blue. I was about to start chemo to shrink my lump when they told me there was a second tumour and I'd need a mastectomy - I then had 5 months to come to a decision though. I didn't have a reconstruction - once I met with the plastic surgeon and got the details, and got everyone's experiences on here, I decided it wasn't for me - I went back and forth with my surgeon over an elective bilateral mastectomy - I had the single in the end with a possibility of the other one if I choose next year. Do you know how soon they will operate and have you discussed your recon options? It might be better to have it at a later date than make a decision in a rush.  I'm sure you'll get some people with more helpful advice - there are definitely people who've had delayed reconstruction. Take care R
Posts.Title: No radiotherapy now mastectomy and ANC

Posts.Content: Hi Sara08 A warm welcome to you too. You most definitely are no longer alone - we are all here to help you through this. It's tough waiting for a treatment plan - hopefully you will get yours soon. It's good that you have your friend as a role model but I understand it wouldn't take away your fear. It hits you in the night, when you wake up, at any random point in the day.... That does fade eventually but it is still early for you. Waiting is the worst bit - it's awful but hopefully you will get some answers this week. A sense of humour is good - it helped me through treatment. Try to distract yourself until you get your treatment plan - not always easy but work- hobbies- decorating - nights out, try to keep busy, basically. Let us know how you get on with your results this week. R
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Sacha I'll echo what LondonLass says - you won't read positive stories because there's no need for people to post them other than to reassure others. Hand on heart - if my team had told me to choose a treatment to do over - I'd pick chemo! The surgery and rads have been harder for me to recover from. That's not to say I had no side effects - but I was able to manage them and get on with life. Fair enough I was told I couldn't work because of the infection risk (I teach) so it might have been harder if I was working too. My chemo nurses were amazing - so honest and positive and the unit was a very upbeat place - lots of chatting, laughing etc. No-one can predict how you'll react but most side effects are manageable with the right drugs and my oncology team and nurses were adamant I shouldn't suffer at all - they were always willing to change my medication if something wasn't working.  Don't panic - take the drugs, get all the advice you can from the chemo club thread here, stick your positive head on and keep telling yourself it's a few months out of your life to buy you many more years! You can do it! R
Posts.Title: Positive FeC-T , or is it all bad

Posts.Content: Hi ask123 It can be scary but try not to worry unduly - we have people here who are many years post treatment and doing well - breast cancer has good success rates. They do use the word treatable - it threw me at first too. It doesn't mean that they think they can't cure you, it's just that they can't guarantee so they don't use the word. Things are unsettling at first but in time, as treatment starts and progresses you get used to it. Try not to think about every scenario because we are all individuals so we don't have the same experience as another person even though the cancer may seem the same to us. Take things one day at a time - we are here to help you through! R

Also, macmillan do have a buddy system in some areas - I really don't know how you find it though - maybe one of the champions would know? Posts.Title: Hickman line gone

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4 Firstly, wishing you a very Happy Birthday for tomorrow! To reassure you - I am 48, diagnosed in February - my original tumour was about 52mm (different measurements on different scans) I had a second tumour in the same breast 6mm - invasive ductal carcinoma both grade 2 with lymph node involvement. I took all the advice from my medical team and told them I was happy to have whatever treatment would give me the best outcome. They have told me several times that they want to throw everything they can at it to have the best possible chance of living as long as possible. They definitely aren't going to tell you it's too big. When I found mine, I was quite complacent as I have very lumpy breasts with lots of cysts (been to the breast clinic before) and waited a couple of months  before seeing the GP. I don't punish myself for that or for not finding it sooner - my consultant wasn't sure the first time he examined me.I did find it, I am  having treatment and the outlook is good. When you see your consultant, you will discuss your options and what is the best treatment for  your individual situation. There will be time for you to get some calm back and make your decisions - if you need time then a week here or there doesn't matter - that's what I was told a few times by my team. Remember, breast cancer is very common - they are very good at treating it and they have your best interests at heart! Wishing you some enjoyment tomorrow!! R
Posts.Title: Large lumps

Posts.Content: Hi The community is an open and welcoming place and we have all agreed to respect each others views. We all have different opinions on many things - in my life I have been ridiculed and criticised for many different things that did not fit with other people's ideas of how I should live and behave - morally, socially, spiritually - I accept and respect their liberty to have and express those opinions and I expect them to extend the same to me. Even a small gesture or comment can make the world a nicer or harsher place for an individual and I think it's important that we do all we can to enhance each others lives - we are all affected by cancer, after all, that's enough. Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Hi LizzieD58 A busy week ahead - glad you are coming to terms with it. Yes, it's very important to drink lots - it helps with the nausea, don't worry, the chemo drugs will stay in your system for a while - that's why people start to feel a bit better after one or two weeks. When I had an infection about a week after a chemo treatment, I was in a single room in A+E with a warning on the door that I was "cytotoxic" and all staff had to wear gloves and apron before entering the room to safeguard themselves - it was still in my system then. You're very well prepared! Have you taken a look at the breast cancer chemo club thread? It's a great place to connect with others going through treatment and the first page has a link to some ideas of what to take etc. Sounds like you've pretty much got it covered though! We'll all be thinking of you! R
Posts.Title: Night terrors

Posts.Content: Hi ask123 I hope you are finding the site and the group helpful. I was diagnosed and treated in 2016 and found it a massive help. As you can see from the replies, we are all different and we all approach things differently. I was a bit "out with it" with my diagnosis - I went to work straight after my biopsy and told everyone, then the day after results told everyone at  2 different workplaces. People probably wish I would shut up about it but it was my way of dealing with it.  I feel that it is up to the individual to choose who and how to tell - I think that other people just have to be considerate enough to understand that. A friend of mine had breast cancer a few years ago and didn't speak to anyone until her treatment was over - her husband sent a group email on her behalf and asked us not to contact her. We were all OK with that because it was how she wanted to handle it. I know family are more difficult because they are closer to you but you already have to cope with a lot so sometimes it can seem like another burden to have to tell your loved ones and then console them. Would it be feasible to ask your sister to tell your parents and your other sister? It might be easier for them if they are told in person? People are very odd sometimes, but your sister may not have been making light of the situation - she might have been trying to convince herself that it was all OK. There is some information on talking about cancer on the site - here is a link to a page that is advice for others about talking to people with cancer. Perhaps you could email it to your sister - hmmm maybe not, depends on your relationship. You might find it helpful to look around that section anyway - to see that you are not alone feeling as you do. There is also information there on talking to children about cancer if that is something that might be helpful for you. At the moment, you are at the worst stage - constant appointments and results and, as you say, the picture getting larger each time because they do like to drip feed us information! As time goes on, it does get easier and hard as it may be to believe now, there will be a day when you look back and think "wow - did all that really just happen to me?" and you will be glad it's over and you will move on. However, you have to walk that treatment path first and none of us would tell you it's a breeze, but you will cope - one day at a time. Feel free to rant as much as you need - that's what we are here for! R
Posts.Title: Telling Family

Posts.Content: Hi Suzeanna Sorry to hear you've had a recurrence - but good that your mammogram picked it up.  Now, I am not a great believer in luck - let's assume you are no more lucky or unlucky than anyone else. Firstly, of course you've read horror stories - if you saw the title "successful uneventful treatment" you wouldn't have read it - we all go looking for the worst case scenario and are seldom disappointed. Hopefully, you will get lots of reassurance here. I don't think you're questioning that the nodes have to go - if you can't have other treatments then it's the best thing so we need to give you some positive stories to encourage you. I wanted to respond because I had my node clearance in October and I AM having some problems! I don't have full mobility (yet) I have some nerve damage and am getting some physio treatment to sort it out. It's uncomfortable, sometimes painful and I can't really return to work until it improves. If I was told I needed nodes removed on the other side, I wouldn't hesitate - I'd have it done again!! I am sure I will get full movement back in time - it doesn't impact on my daily life and the pain is not constant it happens in certain positions. The important thing is - I've been told it's very unusual. I have a result that hardly ever happens - and it's still not that bad. There is always the risk of lymphoedema, but these days that risk is fairly small and if you follow advice you are more likely to avoid it. It can also be managed effectively if it does happen. Please don't panic - it is a good thing that you are informed of all possibilities, however unlikely. As other people respond you will begin to see that this is a fairly common and routine procedure that very seldom causes problems! Hopefully we can all give you the reassurance you need! R
Posts.Title: Terrified at the thought of axillary clearance

Posts.Content: |Hi LizzieD58 and Googieswife  I thought I would pitch in as someone else who fared pretty well through chemo - it's true - those who are off and getting on with life as usual don't normally post. I carried on running through at least half of my chemo - went to some parties, lunches with friends etc etc. It's not exactly a breeze but for the majority of people who are in good health, it is very do-able. It made me tired towards the end, but most of the time it was fine. At my hospital, the chemo introduction was done in the chemo unit so it reassured me no end to see what an upbeat and friendly place it was - not the room full of frail, suffering people I had imagined. We have a breast cancer chemo club thread which you might to look at - a new thread starts each month - here is the March one. The first page has some information about good things to take etc. and then everyone going through chemo can post tips, ask for advice and just generally connect with each other. As for diabetes - I don't really know anything about it but I am going to tag Kacang who may be able to help. She is in Australia so procedures may be different, but I know we have had members with diabetes in the past and there have been quite a few discussions about it here. I know it can be difficult to ask questions - please don't feel that any of them are stupid though - this stuff is new to us all when we start so we need to be told everything and also, it is an emotionally difficult thing to have to deal with - there are no stupid questions. Goodness, if there was a prize for stupid questions, I would definitely have been in the finalists when I was having treatment - "I don't understand" was almost my catchphrase. I was always treated with the utmost respect and understanding. If you really can't face asking questions, how about seeing if there is a way you could email them? You'd get a bit more time to think about them then. Or even just write them down - then you can work through the list verbally or hand it over and let them answer them. One final thing - you don't have to do it if you don't want to. I turned up to my first chemo and told them I'd changed my mind (my diagnosis had changed the day before) They were brilliant - took me to a quiet corner, chatted to me, called an oncologist who spoke to me then went to see my surgeon and came back with some answers. I didn't have it that day but agreed to go back a couple of days later. I'm not remotely suggesting that you should do that, but knowing that you have a choice and are in control might help you to feel better about starting it.  I wish both of you well through it - we are all here to help you through - you can do it! R

Posts.Title: Night terrors

Posts.Content: Hi BevL My hair is only just starting to regrow - still one more chemo to go - so I am not speaking from experience, but I have been a hairdresser for 30 years Cutting your hair will never encourage it to grow thicker or stimulate the growth - it grows very deep within the skin and the cells are long dead by the time you see them. BUT ... sometimes it will look thicker because the hairs will be naturally at different lengths and cutting them short will make them the same length so they look thicker because you see them all (hope that makes some sort of sense) I think the advice to cut it is because it grows fine and a bit "messy" at first. Our amazing bodies will always divert nutrients from our hair (and skin and nails) when we are ill, to where we need it most, so it makes sense that what you first see will not be strong, healthy hair - that will come later. You could keep cutting your hair and as it grows it will gradually look more healthy - or you could leave it and see what it looks like - it won't make any difference to how it eventually grows. Also everyone is different - some people will have the hair they know almost immediately, for other people it can take a year or more to get back to their pre-cancer hair - but it will get there. Just to let you know, I have recently cut the top of mine - it's really thin and wispy there but looks thicker and nicer at the back and sides so I've left them. I'll leave it to grow when I like the look of it! My advice would be to do what feels right for you - it is all about how we feel about how we look!  Enjoy - I think it's such an important positive step! R
