Posts.Title: 1st haircut after vhemo

Posts.Content: Hi dillybub I was told by my chemo nurses not to colour for 6 months after chemo - they said that it was a precaution because the hair follicles were open. As a hairdresser, I would translate this as meaning your scalp will be more sensitive and you could have a skin reaction to the colour. Certainly I would proceed cautiously with anyone post chemo - even with the huge amount I have learned going through this - I still know nothing!!  Ultimately, I would never advise anyone to disregard medical advice. If your hair has been growing since March does that mean you are nearing 6 months post chemo? Highlights can be done so as to be nowhere near your scalp, and there are other products that can be used (most permanent and "semi" permanent hair colours contain ingredients which are known irritants and allergens)  There is also a possibility that the colour won't give the same result as usual - hormones, drugs, different health conditions all have an effect on the hair. If you have a regular hairdresser that you trust - speak to them. Chances are you are not their first client to have gone through cancer treatment. They will know you and be able to suggest alternatives if they are not happy to colour it - don't leave it too close to the wedding though in case you decide to get used to a new look. Finally, I will tell you my philosophy as someone who makes a living changing the way people look: Everyone in this world is beautiful as they are, changing that is helping to create a version of beautiful that is different but not better or worse. I bet your grey curls look fantastic, even though they are not what you are used to! Good luck with achieving the hair that you want and wishing you the most enjoyable time at your son's wedding - what a wonderful thing to look forward to! R

Posts.Title: Keep a diary

Posts.Content: Hi Athena18 I am so sorry that you find yourself here, but we are a very friendly bunch - all here to support you and your family in whatever way we can. I can well imagine how shocked you are and, I am sure your minds are racing - full of questions. Firstly, please know that breast cancer is very treatable. I had grade 2 breast cancer in 2016 - it spread to at least 3 lymph nodes. I also had mastectomy, chemotherapy and radiotherapy and am here to tell you that we get through and we pick up our lives again. Success rates for treatment are really high and we have women here who finished treatment years ago. Try to stay away from the darker places on the internet - stick to reputable sites - Macmillan, of course, Breast Cancer Care and Cancer Research UK. I am sure your sister is in shock and she will likely be guided through this step by step by her medical team. If she feels like it, she is more than welcome to join us too. I see that Dreamthief has already replied to your post in Family and Friends but I wanted to say Hi here too and say that you are more than welcome to use as many groups on here that you feel are appropriate, so please don't apologise - you didn't post incorrectly at all - we are just all so eager to help and get you the most appropriate support possible. You may have seen the helpline number 0808 808 00 00 (Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm) it is for anyone affected by cancer so you are welcome to call if you need to talk, as is your sister and the rest of your family. My daughter called when I was having treatment and felt so much better afterwards. We've got you now and we will give you as much support as you need, whenever you need it - there's usually people around at all sorts of hours. Best wishes to your sister and all of you R
Posts.Title: Little sister diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi oks thought I'd pop on and share my experience. I did develop a seroma after my mastectomy. It was drained once and came right back again. My surgeon was really not in favour of draining it - he said every time they put a needle in it, there's an infection risk so he doesn't like to do it. He advised compression - I wore a sports bra every day. To be honest, it didn't seem to help much, but I got rather ill soon after so maybe it would have if I'd continued with it - I did it for about a month. it is the pain that is difficult to handle, so I think they would drain them to ease that for you. It's not an easy road is it? Unfortunately they can take a long time to get rid of, but why don't you sit down and have a chat either with your surgeon or BCN about the best way to approach this. I think different hospitals - or even different surgeons - have different opinions so it's good to talk it through. Wishing you some ease from it! R
Posts.Title: Post MX seromai pain

Posts.Content: Hi I just thought I'd throw a couple of things into the mix. My SNB showed 3 out of 3 nodes affected and my surgeon advised clearance. He's fairly young for a consultant so not exactly old-fashioned, but maybe a bit 'belt and braces' He was adamant he thought it was the best option. I had the clearance and radiotherapy - they only found one more node that showed evidence of cancer but that reassured me and I felt I had a good picture of the situation. Without the clearance I am the sort of person who would worry about how far the cancer had gone. I have had nerve damage that has taken time to repair and numbness and am left with a small dog ear which irritates my arm. I still don't regret the clearance but that is related to the type of person I am and for some people, avoiding clearance makes sense and I am sure will become the norm - just as WLE is now preferred to mastectomy. Radiotherapy isn't without problems - it hardens tissues which can take at least a year to then soften and stretch out.  SNB and rads do also carry a small risk of lymphoedema though not as much as clearance, true. I fear lymphoedema but my surgeon told me current thinking is it affects about 20% of women. Some of those will be people who don't follow the advice on avoiding it. Having clearance won't stop your lymph system working - it just means the normal pathway won't be there but you should be shown a drainage massage to re-direct it to the nodes in your neck and your other armpit. It's really a question of what you will be happiest living with - we can't predict what physical side effects we will get, so it might be easier to make the decision that will be best for you psychologically. R
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance or radiotherapy, what to do??

Posts.Content: Hi LisaD81 Welcome - hope you're treatment continues well! Do take Dreamthiefs advice and check out the chemo club thread - I found this site when I was almost finished chemo and wished I had found it earlier - loads of really useful advice - it's the little things that make such a difference! Good luck with the rest of your treatment! R
Posts.Title: Just started chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Nessa1422 bras and prosthesis - one of my pet subjects! My mastectomy was October 2016 - I wear knitted knockers most of the time and sometimes a lightweight foam form from M+S. I found the silicone prosthesis too heavy. Although it's not really heavy and doesn't weigh as much as the tissue that was removed, - the weight is all on the bra strap so it made my shoulders too sore. Maybe I should have persevered but at that time, I really felt I'd been through enough and gave up on it. - I keep it in a drawer for "best" but have no idea what that would be!!!! Anyway - One thing I have learnt is that I was wearing my bras too big/loose around the band. I had a bra fitting before my mastectomy and the lovely woman told me that the band should be tighter to reduce the strain on the straps and pressure on the shoulders. I still sometimes wear a bra slightly too big because I struggle to find the right size (small band, larger cup) and I find that in the looser bras, the knitted knockers ride up more. I'd totally agree with going to an event and getting some info from the professionals, but in the meantime, it might be a short-term solution to go for a bra fitting and check you are wearing the right size bra - maybe you already have. I also think the style of bra helps - have you tried shopping around for different styles? I think it is a real process to get it right and I hope you find a solution soon! R

Posts.Title: Starting radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzy4u I agree with the others that it's worth switching brands if you haven't already tried that. But I also wanted to say that I was very stiff with a lot of joint pain and quite bad peripheral neuropathy after chemo. My oncologist warned me it could take up to 2 years for that to stop. The PN has more or less gone and now the joint pain is only there after long periods of being still. It's just over a year since my last chemo. I do think exercise helped me - not a lot yet but some gentle running and walking every day and some strength training. For me - movement seems to be key - the more time I spend in any position - sitting at a desk, standing on a train etc then the more it will ache. A six hour drive a couple of months ago left me really stiff for a couple of days. So - you can try coming off it, try different brands, try an alternative - hopefully you will be able to find a solution that works for you. R

Posts.Title: Itching I can't scratch

Posts.Content: Hi WORRIED2016 Here is a link to the FAQ page of the R1/R2 website - it's explained there better than on the leaflet in the box. Basically the R2 is 4 times a day, most importantly at bedtime. The R1 is for immediately after treatment but needs to air dry for 20 minutes so that can be tricky - it gets very sticky as it dries so if you dress while it's wet, your clothes will stick to it and it's a bit unpleasant peeling them off! (tried it) It can be applied up to 4 hours after treatment, though - but before R2. There - clear as mud? But yes - don't put cream on skin before treatment - when I had pm appointments I used to put the R2 on in the morning but shower before I left for the hospital. www.radiotherapytreatment.com/.../ Hope it all goes well! R

Posts.Title: Stage 3 breast cancer help & how to tell my children

Posts.Content: Hi Matohu First a congratulations on finishing treatment - woo hoo! You've already been given great advice - I thought I'd add a little more. You could look at attending a moving forward or next steps event. Lots of hospitals offer them and so do Maggies centres and Breast Cancer Care. The haven also offer some therapies including counselling. You could check your hospital website or the In Your Area section of this website. I found out I could access acupuncture, hormone clinics, yoga, mindfulness, physical rehabilitation - lots of things. I have also fairly recently read a book called The Cancer Survivors Companion. There are a few similar ones - I liked this one because it also deals with how those close to you might be feeling and has advice for them as well. I found it really helpful dealing with all the other repercussions from cancer that I hadn't thought about - self-esteem, confidence in my abilities at work etc etc There is a lot of support out there, but I do think you need to work quite hard to find it sometimes and find what is right for you. I never joined any support groups, but I do volunteer now and I find it really helps to talk to other people who have been through it - just knowing that you aren't going to be upsetting anyone by talking about cancer is a massive relief. Do have a look at what is available - the recovery is as much a part of the process as the treatment. R
